docTitle.titlePart:
A book of remembrances of
all the remarkable deliverances
of my self, Husband & Children
with their births, & other remarks
as concerning my self & Family
beginning from the year. 1625 .

div.p:
Alice Wandesforde the
fifth child of Christopher
Wandesforde Esquire & late
Lord Deputy of Ireland.
was born at Kirklington
the thirteenth day of february
being monday, about two of
the clock in the after noone, in
the year. 1625 Baptised
the next day.

Witnesses, Mr Lassells minister
of Kirklington. Mrs Anne
Norton and Mrs Best.

div.l: Lord guide my heart,
and give my Soul directions:
Subdue my passions
Curb my Stout affections:
Nip thou the bud,
Before the bloom begins
Lord the ever one keep me, from
Presumptuous sins:
Lord lead me by thy hand into thy rest
And make me everto choose what thou sest best
I'll dedicate my Soul unto my God
My Childhood, non-Age, youth, is by his Rod.
To be directed, his Staff to uphold.
My Age, and riper years till it has told.
The gracious goodness of our blessed God.
What he has done for me & by his word.
Raised my drooping Spirits often times.
Pardoned my Sins delivered me from Crimes.
And by his bloodshed Purchased Heaven.
For humblest Souls his Grace has given.
Then on my soul, doe not decline,
This Heavenly Pilgrimage divine.
Rise up my heart to Heaven above
And let thy Lord now Prove thy love.
Spring up amaine and let his holy Spirit
give thee a Crown of Glory to Inherit.
Then fly apace, stay not behind.
For to be drove by every wind
And trifling. childish, foolish. Toys.
To interrupt thy lasting solid Joys.
which are ever living. never ending.
where are pleasures worth commending.

div.head: Prayer.
div.l: Then guide my heart, Lord give my Soul direction
Subdue my passions, Curb my stout affections
Nip thou the bud, before the bloom begins
Lord ever keep me from Presumptuous sins
And make me Choose what thou seest best
Lord lead me by thy hand into thy Rest.
div.p: Amen.

div.head: observations.
div.p:
These things be comely & pleasant
to see, & worthy of honour from the
beholders; A young Saint. An old
martyr; A Religious Soldier A
Conscionable Statesman; A great man
Courteous; A learned man humble;
A silent woman; A Child understand
-ing the Eye of his Parent; A merry
Companion without vanity; A friend
not Changed with honour; A Sick man
Cheerful: And a departing Soul with
Comfort and Assurance.

div.head: Prayer.
div.p:
Lord lead me through the
Red Sea of this World,
Into the Land of Promise,
Forget my many iniquities,
Pardon my Sins which stands
As a cloud between thy most
Gracious goodness and my.
most extreme misery. for
our Lord Jesus Christ his Sake.
Amen.

For as much as it is the duty.
of every true Christian to take
notice of Almighty God our Father's
gracious dealings with them from the
womb, until the grave bury them in
Silence & to keep particular remem-
-brances of his remarkable deliver-
-ances of their Souls & bodies with
a true & unfeigned gratitude to his
majesty. I therefore humbly desire to
furnish my heart with the deep thoughts
of his Love. mercies. & inconceivable
goodness to me his poor Creature
even from the first beginning of my dais
& with a thankful heart doe return
him the Glory for my birth, baptism in
the most holy name of God & education in that
true faith by my Pious & Religious
Parents who instilled the principles of his
Grace into
10
me with my milk. and therefore
shall begin with the first mention of
my deliverances since my first know-
ledge & remembrance most worthy
of a perpetual memory, which I hope
shall
not , end with this life but spring
up to an Eternity of Hallelujahs of
praise to all Eternity Amen.

When I was left at Richmond
in under
the care & dear love of my beloved &
gracious Aunt Norton upon my fathers
going to London. It pleased God to
bring me into a very great weakness
& sickness upon the accident of a surfeit
on some ill digested meat, causing an
extreme vomiting, whose violence drove
me into a fever & the measles which
brought me so low that my Aunt & Sara
Tomlinson our maid almost despaired
of my Life.

But it pleased the Lord in great
mercy upon the hearty Prayers &
requests of my dear Aunt. that
I was spared & upon the use of good
means by his blessing there on I
recovered my health perfectly again
Oh that I may have my life
given me for a blessing & that I may
live to the Praise of his holy name
growing in Grace & the knowledge of
our Lord Jesus Christ being a comfort
to my dear Parents & relations
& that I may dedicate my Childhood.
youth. middle Age. & old Age. if
God shall spare me so long to his
Glory & praise even to my lives end
Amen. & that for my Saviours Sake
alone. the Alpha & Omega. Amen.

Being removed from Richmond
to London by my Fathers & mothers
order to be with them. I fell into the
Small Pox having taken them of
my brother Christopher, we were both
sent into Kent with Sarah to one
Mr Baxters house where we were being
much beloved & taken care for by them
And by the blessing of God I recovered
very soon, nor was I very ill at
that time in thim. I will praise the
Lord our God for my Preservation &
deliverance that did not suffer that disease
to rage & endanger my life. but
Raised me soon to my Parents again
O let me speak good of the name of
the Lord & magnify his goodness for
my self & my Brother.

After this it pleased the Lord to
begin to come into my soul by some
beams of his mercy in putting good
Thoughts into my mind to consider
his Great & miraculous Power in
the Creation of the Heavens. the Earth
& all therein, contained upon the
Reading of my daily Psalms for the
months which happened that day to be Psalm
147 verse the 4th

He counteth the Stars & calleth
them all by there names. from
whence there came a forcible consid
-eration of the Incomprehensible Power
& infinite majesty of Almighty
God. who made all things. in the Hea
-vens & the Earth. being above all his
Creatures in the world. & knew what
was.
14 1631.
In my heart & thoughts &
knew I was but a Child in Age
& understanding. not able to doe
any good thing. which caused a deep
& great apprehension & fear,
with awe of his Glorious majesty
least I should offend him at any
time by sin. against him or my
Parents, & that he would punish all
sins. it also caused in me a
love to him my Creator. that had
made me to serve him, & his per-
rticuler love & grace to me a little
child, in giving me understanding
& reason to know there is a God that
Ruleth in heaven & Earth, & to reward
them that serves him truly. with Joy in Heaven
that should never have end.

There was a great fire in the next
House to my fathers in St martins
Lane in London, which burned a part
of our house & had like to have
burned our house, but was prevented
through the care of our servants.
this was done at night when my
father & mother was at Court. but
we were preserved in my Lady
Levertons House. being carried by
Sara thither. this fire did seem to
me as if the day of Judgment was
come & caused great fear & trembling
but we were all delivered from
Ruin by that fire all though my Father
had great loss. but blessed be the Lord
my God who gave us not over to this
cruel Element of fire but preserved
us from all evil at that time.

It pleased God to give me a
safe passage with my mother & her
family into Ireland a bout the year
1632: my Father being there before
and sent for us over. where I enjoyed
great happiness & comfort during
my fathers life and had the opportuni
ty of the best education that Kingdom
could afford in the sweet & excellent
company of my Lord of Strafford's
Daughters. the most virtuous
Lady Anne Wentworth & Arbella
learning those qualities with them
my Father pleased to order me, as
The french language. writing, &
speaking the same. Singing. Dancing
Playing on the Lute, & Theorbo.

learning also all the other accomp
-lighmets of working silks &
sweetmeats & by my dear mothers
virtuous provision. & care she brought
me up in all those suitable to that
quality as my Fathers child. But above
all these things. I accounted it my
chief happiness in those Pious. holy
& religious, instructions, Examples,
admonitions, Teachings, reproofs, &
Godly education, tending to the Eternal
happiness. & Salvation of my poor soul
which I Received from. both my Hon.rd
father & mother. with their Chaste &
sober Conversation in all things of
this world. For all which things. & infinitely
more opportunities of Good to my wellbeing
then I can express. I most humbly &
heartily acknowledge my bounden
duty of
18
35, 36, 37.
of thanks & Praise to the great
God of heaven & Earth. in the first
place from whence comes every
good & perfect gift, the Author &
finisher of our faith. and next
I humbly acknowledge, my faith-
-ful thanks & gratitude to my
dear & Hon.red Parents for their
exceeding great love & painful
care. & affection for the performance
of their part towards me. desiring
of God to give me grace to live in
holy obedience to all there goodness
of God & theirs, & that I may perform
my cordial duty to them; in all
godly honesty & righteous, in obeying
my parents in the Lord, to the end. of
their Lives Amen.

While we were in Ireland there was
a fire in our house in Dublin which by
a providence was quenched with out
much harm.

38.. About the time I was 12 years old. I
was reading of the great wisdom of
our Saviour in the Gospel where he
was disputing with the Doctors with so much
power that he put them to silence. upon
which place, in the reading thereof being
that day 12 y. old. I fell into a deep
thought of the majesty of Jesus X
who was able to confound the Doctors
at that Age. And then I considered
my childishness & folly that could not
scarce understand mean & low things
& begged of him to give me knowledge
, wisdom, & understanding to guide
& preserve me to my lives end for
his mercy's sake. Amen.

Having come over into England
with my d. mother to the bath for the stone
in our return back to Ireland August
22th 39. I with the rest of the Ship &
the passengers was delivered from that
great & terrible Storm
in Neston
water where there was 5 ships cast
away before we took ship. but the
same great God that maketh the storms
to cease brought us safely out of that
storm. & carried us well to the Land
though in great fright & much
distress. I praise the Lord. who brought
my soul out of the deep waters &
fathomless gulf of waters. praise
his holy name for ever & for ever Amen

I had a second preservation from drowning
out of the ship at that time when a
cable had like to have pulled me into
the sea but for a ship man that saved
me as I was half over. bless the Lord
o my soul & forget not the deliverance
Amen.

It pleased God to call for my dear
& Hon.red Father by a fever of
6 days continuance after a relapse
by going to church & came sick home.
who departed sweetly in the Lord, to the
infinite loss of me & the rest of our family
Dec. 3d 40 at his house in dublin
in Ireland.

It was amongst the many 1000 of others
Protestants in Ireland miraculously pre-
-served from that Horrid Rebellion in Ireld
which broke out, & was discovered in Dublin
October. 3d 1641 October: 23d 1641
: but it was acted with
bitter malice. & fury against the English
in the country for many days together
fire & sword to all in general. till it
was known to be prevented in Dublin.
but we were tossed with frights & Alarms
for 14 days after till my mother did
get over with all her family to Weschester
which blessed be God in great & wonderful
mercy. we did & came safe to Land at
Neston Beere house. from thence to the
City of Chester

I got the smallpox at weschester
of my brother John. & was very near
death with them. but blessed be the God
of mercies who spared my life at that
time also. with my brother: John who had them
but a poor boy F. Kelly died of them. then.

we were prevented from the siege at
york by Mr Danbys advice being
got half way thither, 42.

I got a surfeit at Richmond, with
eating a piece of Lobster. that day I
had taken Physic. which had like to
have proved my last. being brought
exceeding weak through vomiting
1643.
& purging. but by the blessing of God
upon Mr mahums advices & my mother
And good Aunt Nortons care I escaped
& yet lives to render him the glory &
praise of all his wonderful deliverances
& mercies. Bless the Lord o my Soul
and all that is within thee praise
his holy name for ever. Amen.

my Sister Danby died at Thorpe Sept 10th
1645
of her 16 child. being a son named
Francis which I baptised

My Cozen Edmund Norton married
Mr Dudlys Daughter & heir of.
Chopwell. Jane Dudly. the 10th of
February. 1647. at Chopwell.

My Cousin Edmund Norton died at
Yorke of a pleurisy, or stitch in his
side, the 30th of November: 1648.

King Charles the first beheaded at
White hall, London the 30th of January,
1648.

My Cozen Julian Norton died at
Richmond Greene at her fathers the
9th of April. 1649.

my Cozen John Norton died at St.
Nicholas.

my Uncle Sir Ed. Osborne died at Keevetn
of a surfeit of eating melons. being too cold
for him.

my brother George Wandesforde
was drowned Riding over the Swale at
Hipswell was going to Richmond
to my uncle will. wandesforde, the 31
of March 1651.

My Cozen mary Norton was Married
to Mr John Vorke at her fathers
house on the Greene in Richmond, the
12th of August 1651.

My Brother Christopher Wandesford
married Sir John Lowthers eldest
Daughter Mrs Elleanor Lowther, the.
30th of September. 1651. at Lowther.

My Self Alice Wandesforde was
married to William Thornton Esquire
At my mothers house in hipswell the
15th of December. 1651. Married by
Mr Syddall.

I began my great Sickness after
I came from Barne Park the first time
about the 6th of August 1652 & miscar-
-ried of my first Child being a
daughter the 27th of the same August 1652
being friday. & she was buried at
Easby Church near Rich. the next morn
ing: the effects of which sickness lasted by
an Ague. fever, & Jaundice 3 qrters of a
year: at hipswell.

Alice Thornton my Second Child
was borne at Hipswell the 3d of January
1653
and Baptised the 4th of the same.

witnesses my Mother, my Uncle Major
norton and Cozen Yorke his Daughter
; she was borne on a Tuesday between the
hours of 5 and 6 a clock in the affter
noone. Christened by Mr Syddall. 4th

Elizabeth Thornton my third Child
was borne at Hipswell the 14th of february
1654
being Wednesday. half hour
after 11 a clock in the forenoon, and
26 1654.
was Baptised the 16th of February by
Mr Antony. witnesses, my Mother
my Aunt Norton and my brother
Christopher wandesforde, Mrs Black
burne stood for my Mother being sick
then.

my Mother Gates died at
Oswoldekirke of the voidance of
blood the 10th day of may. 1655.
& was buried at Stonegrave
the 11th of may 1655.

my father Gates died at Hull
the 18th of may 1655. and was
buried at hull the 18th of may
1655

My brother. Richard Thornton
died in Dublin, in Ireland of the flux
country disease the 3d of July
1656. & buried in St Patrick's
Church the next day.

Katherine Thornton my fourth
Child was born at Hipswell the
12th of June, 1656. being thursday
about half an hour after 4
a clock in the affter noone, and was
baptised the 1th of June. by Mr
Syddall. witnesses, my mother,
my Niece K Danby, & Mr Thornton

Elizabeth Thornton my 3d child
died the: 5th of September 1656.
betwixt the hours of 5 and 6 in the
morning, of a cough gotten at first
by an Ague. & much gone in the
Rickets caused by ill suck at
2 nurses. her age was 1 year
28 1657.
6 months &. 21 days. was
buried the same day at Catericke
Church by Mr Syddall.

I got a great fall over the
Threshold in the hall at Hipswell
being great with Child of my
fifth Child wanting but
ten weeks. before of my time
the 14th of September: 1657
which cast me into an ill fit
of a fever, and the Jaundice
about 3 weeks very weak
likely to have miscarried, but
it pleased God to restore me
of Dr witty who let me blood
& I went to my full time. Blessed be
the most high God Deviser of Heaven & Earth &

I was delivered of my fifth
Child being a goodly Son
upon the 10th day of December
1657 between the hours
of 2 and 3 a clock in the
morning upon Thursday
having had very sore travel
endanger of my Life from
that time in the morning on
wednesday. caused by the
Childs coming into the world with
his feet first, and so caused
him to be strangled almost
in the birth. he lived about
half an hour so died, and
was buried in Cattericke Church
the same day by Mr Syddall:
he was Turned wrong in my womb
by the fall I had in Sept. before

1658
The weakness of my body continued
So great and long after my hard Child
birth of my son. that it brought me
almost into a consumption. non expect
-ing for many days together that I
1658
should at all recover. & when it was don
I was lame almost a quarter of a year of
my left knee, that I got in my labour.
but this was nothing to that which I
have deserved from the hand of God if
he in much mercy had not spared my
life .The Lord make me truly remember
his goodness & that I may never forget
this above all his mighty & stretched
out hand of deliverances to me his
poor Creature. that I may extol &
praise the Lord with all my soul & never
let go my hope from the God of my
salvation but live the remainder of the
life he gives me to his hon.or and Glory
& at the last may praise him eternally in the
heavens. bless the Lord My soul & forget
not all his benefits Amen. Amen.

It pleased God to visit my
dear & hon.red Mother the Lady
Wandesford with her last sickness
upon Friday the 17th of november 1659 beginning
then 18th an exceeding great Cough
tormenting her body by stitches in
her breast, & short breathing;
these stitches continued a bout 14
days with the Cough hindering her from
almost any sleep. when upon the
use of bags with fried oats, butter
& Chamomile chopped laid to her sides
the stitches removed, any the Cough
abated as to the extremity thereof.
but then she was seized with a more
dangerous symptom, of a hard lump
contracted in her stomach that laid on
her heart; with great pain, & rising
up to her throat almost stopping her
breath when she either swallowed any
thing or laid to sleep.

Which lump was conceived to
be contracted of Phlegm & wind,
in the Stomach for lack of voidance.
: She had also an exceeding sore
throat & mouth so that she was
deprived of the benefit to swallow
all most any kind of food. Even
to a little drop of beer, which was
for 4 days or 5 the most she
took inwardly. & that but with
a searing. The Tongue & mouth
at first was black. then turned
white, so that with the Pains my dear
mother took in washing & cleans
-ing the skin came of like a callous
Tongue, & was raw & red till the
blood came. but this continued
and in the end grew with a white
skin all over.

In this condition of weakness
was my dear mother, almost
quite with out food, rest, ease
or sleep for a bout a week, in
which time, as in all her sickness
she expressed extraordinary great
patience, still saying the Lord had
sent it to her & non could take it
from her. & if he pleased he could ease
her & that the way to heaven was by the
gates of hell, she was an example
and pattern of Piety, faith, &
patience in her greatest torment.
still with Godly instructions, gentle
rebukes for Sin, a continual pray
ing of Psalms suitable for her
condition, speaking to God in his own
phraise & word, saying that we could
not speak to him from our selves
34 1659.
in such acceptable a manner as
by that which was dictated by his
own most holy Spirit.
When that any did pray for her
she desired they would not pray for
her life, but that these should be
the heads on which they should petition
God for her.

That the Lord would be pleased to
grant her true, & unfeigned repentance
for her sins.

To give her remission & forgiveness
through Jesus Christ her Saviour.
To grant her faith in him, with the
sanctification of his holy Spirit
And at last to Glorify her in hea
-ven. which petitions said she whosoe
-ver shall make for me. the Lord hear
and grant the same.

She had always a great & unfeigned
love for all Gods ministers. & often
desired their prayers, giving great atten-
-tion to them, having much comfort
in her soul after that ordinance.
her desire was to receive the holy sacra-
-ment which she did with comfort the Thursday
was seven night before she departed from
Mr Peter Samois. although it was with
great difficulty of swallowing. never
tasting dry bread after, for the weakness.
Her desire was to Mr Kearton he would
preach her funeral sermon, Text to be
out of the 14th of Revelation 13 verse.
Blessed are the Dead that die in the lord. & so
to the end:

This blessed soul had the gift from God
as to continue till the last breath her
perfect memory, understanding &
great wisdom & Piety.

Ever recommending her soul with de
-sire to be dissolved & so be with Christ
And all the friday night before she died
Come Lord Jesus, come quickly.
she making Dafeny to pray with her
the prayer which Dr Smith made in his
book for a Person at the point to dye
& took great notice of each Petition
praying the same with Zeal and Earnest
-nesse.

About Thursday at night she sent
for her Children to take her leave
when Mr Th. & my self came, &
prayed with her, & so took the saddest
Leave of my Dear Parent as ever
Child could, to part with so great
a comfort, she praying for us, our
Children. & all her friends with her
blessings for us. both.

It pleased God she continued
till saturday about noon when
she spoke to my uncle norton & re-
comended her Children to his care
with much good prayers for him & his
then took her leave of him.

Towards 6 a clock at night her
speech failed & still she could lift
up her hands to God. And Dafeny
prayed her that she would give them some
sign that she found the comfort of Gods
spirit in her soul as with a taste of the
Joys of heaven, which she immediately
did and lift up both hands & eyes to
heaven 3 times. & closing her Eyes
her self. that sweet Saint fell asleep
in the Lord. between the hours of 6 7 &
7 9
o'clock at night upon saturday the
10th of December. 1659

She was interred upon Tuesday
following the 13th of December in the Chiefest
place in her quire at Catrick Church
being Carried out of her house by
the Lord Darcy. his son Mr Coniers.
Sir Christ. vivill & divers kindred
of quality. then from hipswell Green
her Tenants took her so to the
tours End of Catrick where the minist
ers appointed by her did carryr her
into the grave Church, & so to the grave
after sermon. The ministers names
were.

Mr Samois. Mr Kearton, Mr Edrington
Mr Binlows. Mr Robinson, Mr Smith,
Mr Farrer, Mr Brockell, Mr Parke.
Dr Witty was her Physician but
could not come only sent Dr Atie with diuretics
For her. she had also Dr Smith at the begining
of her sickness. but liked him not:

p.add: Enter her Prayers my mo. made on Several occans

div.p:
It was the good pleasure of God
to continue me in the Land of the
living, And to bring forth my 6th
Child at St Nicholas upon the 12th
1660. of April & after hard Labour
& hazardous was in his mercy
delivered of a strong goodly Son
about 3 or 4 a clock in the morning
being Tuesday: 12 April. 1660 Tuesday: 17 April. 1660 :

The Child being baptised that
day by Mr Kearton of Richmond
called william.

sureties my Cousin Jo. Yorke: Co.
Will. Norton. & Co. Darcy of Rich.

My pretty babe was in good hea
-lth & Sucked his poor mother
to whom my good God had given
the blessing of the breast as well as
the womb of that child but on
the friday sennight he began to be angr
-y & after taking Gascon's powder
40 1660.
having had 3 hours sleep his
face was full of roud Red spots
like the smallpox with white weals
continuing in his face till night
& then, whether through cold or
what else the Lord knows. they struck
1660
in, and he waned sick all night
and a bout 9 a clock on Saturday
morning sweetly departed this
life to the great discomfort of his
weak mother. whose only comf-
-ort is that the Lord had received him
to that place of rest in heaven where
little children, beholds the face of
their heavenly father, to his God
& my God whom I humbly crave
to Cleanse me from my sins by the
blood of my Saviour & Redeemer
and that my Soul may be bettered
by these chastisements that hath
41
1660.
Laid heavy upon me for these
many years where in the Lord hath
chastened & corrected me but not
given me over to destruction. his
glorious name be Magnified for
Ever. And I beseech him to sanctify
these fatherly rebukes & make them
profitable to my poor Soul to
bring me nearer in communion with
him self, that so I may be prepared for
his glory. both in this world & the
next even for Christ Jesus his
son's sake amen.

My Child was buried at Easby in
the same grave with his Eldest sister
by Mrs Kearton who preached of
Sunday:

div.l: Tax not thy God thy own defaults
did urge.
This two fold punishment .the
mill. the Scourge
Thy Sins the author of thy self.
tormenting.
Thou grindest for Sinning.
Scourged for not repenting.
I doe not beg a Slender inch
to while.
The time a way, or falsely to beguile,
my self with Joys.
Hears nothing worth a Smile
what' Earth. or in it that longer then a minute
can lend a free delight. that can endure.
Oh who would droil. or delve in such
A Soil.
When gain's uncertain & the pain
Is sure.

div.p:
I began a dangerous sickness at
oswoldkirke after my dear mother
death, being caused by a cold I
got in that church, causing a very great
and violent vomiting upon shrove
tuesday 1661 feb. 13th so continuing till
I was not able to receive any kind
of sustenance, being in an intermi
-ting fever, was compelled to send
for Dr Wittie, which let me blood, &
gave many cordials to strengthen
my stomach, but nothing would stay
with me. till I drank a draught
of cold water which more refreshed
my thirsty soul then what art
could give, that night being
the 17th of feb. I did verily believe should
be my last in this life being brought
into exceeding great weakness of
Body. but more of spiritual deser-
-tion. apprehending my state to be
44 1661.
in a lost condition, by reason of
my sins, & sorrows satan accusing
me, & casting multitude of doubts
into my heart, As that surely I did
not belong to God because he followed
me with such great Crosses Afflictions
& troubles, which seemed to be Curses,
rather then, such trials as he used
to lay upon those that were his children
& that. I had neglected all those off
-er & tenders of mercies which he had
from time to time given me from my
youth up. in the Examples, instruction
admonition of my dear Parents first
& then by his ministers in the word &
sacraments, his great deliverances all
the days of my life innumerable. yet
all these had not wrought a through
conversion & change of heart in me
to walk according to his motions
45
1661.
by his spirit & that now it was
too late to hope because I had driven it
so long that my life was at an end
for ought I knew this was my last
summons, And that although God
was able to have mercy upon me: yet
I had so often fallen into sin & forget
-fullnesse of of God; that he would not
have mercy upon me at the last hour
these with much more arguments
against my poor soul. did that old
serpent seek to destroy my hopes of
mercy, my own conscience framing
arguments against it self joining with
him as being conscious of my own
unworthiness.

In this most sad & heavy condition I
was, having no soul living that I could
open my thoughts to nor receive any
comfort for my heavy spirit: God seemy
ly
46
1661.
to forsake me, the devil, accusing
my Conscience, my sickness & weakness
threatening my dissolution each minute.
yet did I desire to cast my self solely
at the feet of the most gracious God
whom I had offended & though he should
kill me yet would I trust in him
for pardoning. & strengthening mercy.
And it pleased him in a most wonderful
manner to give me some comfort and
stay when I was almost past all
hope out of that blessed portion of
scripture which our blessed saviour spoke
in St Matthew The 11 Chapter
& 28 verses. 29, 30 which like light
-ning pierced into the secret of my heart
& soul bringing relief & some hopes of
comfort. by his sweet & effectual call
come unto me all yea that labour & are
heavy Laden; & I will give you rest

I laboured under & was heavy
Laden underwith
the burden of my Sins.
under the bandage of Satan,
The one bringing me to slavery. the
other of shame & torment, perswa-
-ding me time was past for any help
but Lo, the Lion of the Tribe of Judah
put to flight this Prince of darkness
which deceives the poor weak Christian
Making him doubt of that rich goodness
that is Eternally in God as his very
being, and at this very time Christ
Jesus the righteous came into my
thoughts with healing under his wings
making it appear that satan was a
liar; he calls, he invites; he perswad
-es me to come unto him: he it
was that give me this scripture to stay
my drooping heart even ready to
faint for want of spiritual food.
I was weary. & he said come.

I was faint & heavy Laden.
he said come unto me all the that Labour
& are heavy Laden. & I will give
you rest. Lord if thou art pleased
to call all that are weary that Labour
why should not I come. thou hast
promised to give me rest, I need it
I want it, I cry unto thee, out of
the whales belly of despair, O god
the father of Heaven heave mercy
upon me. o Christ the Redeemer
of the world have mercy upon me, &
O Holy blessed & glorious spirit
have pity upon me, O most glorious
Trinity, 3 persons & one God, help
thy poor distressed weak handm
-aid plunged in the depth of sine
& misery which non but thy Almighty
power is able to help deliver &
save from the Jaws of the Devil.
49
1661.
seeking to devour & make a prey
of my soul, & as thy holy wisdom
O blessed Trinity did set thy self on
work by & through mercy, &
Almighty Power to find out a way
for mans Redemption. of thy free
grace thou o my dear Saviour
suffered the wrath of thy father
upon the Cross to purchase our salv-
-ation. so now art thou pleased
to vanquish my grand Enemy by
the Power of thy word to me.
I believe, (Lord help my unbelief)
that thou art as merciful to me
as others who falls by sine, And yet
art thou pleased to give me plenty
of calls. & comforts, who in my
sad hour was a God of compassion
. I come o Lord to thee, with all my
powers & faculties of my heart &
soul. though weak yet with an
50
1661.
desire unfeigned, & hope of thy
clemency & sweetest mercy. that it
will not be in vain that this thy
word came into my heart. this was
from thy goodness, to let me see
that the Time was not past to come
unto thee. Thou most sweetly
calling me at that present when
my heart was in doubt.

I come o my god, and take up thy
sweet yoke & follow thee. O
Learn me to be patient meek
& lowly in heart, for thy yoke is
easy, & thy burden is light. yea
thy ways is perfect freedom.
Let me for ever make thee my
pattern, my comfort, my life &
direction, so shall I find rest to
my soul. rest, o, how sweet
is that word to my Languishing
51
1661.
soul. O let me find rest from
sinning, from offending thee.
any more. It is too much that I
have spent so many of my years
in sin, Let me now work for
thee, love thee, delight in thee
& fear nothing but thee spending
the remainder of my days to the
Glory of thy name. being never
more a shame to my profession as
a Christian by my unprofitable
life nor give Satan any more ad-
vantage, to tempt my soul
to sine, or despair, and this I
humbly beg for thy mercy sake
o blessed Jesus Amen.

After this inestimable mercy
which my gracious God did give me
in the satisfaction of my spiritual
doubts. he was pleased to suffer
my soul to receive comfort. & my
body strengthened by degrees &
by the use of good means till
I had recovered in part my health
yet my strength was much imp
-ared & for a quarter of a year I did
not fully recover.

At which time I found my self with
quick child, A blessing I could not
hope, or Expect, after so dangerous
& desperate a condition where in the
Dr did verily believe that I could not
retain the conception after that violent
extremity of vomiting which loosened
the womb exceedingly. but blessed
be the gracious goodness. & mercy of
God
53
16622
which rebuked the fever & gave
me means to help the weakness of
my nature, giving me a fresh supply
of all remedies fit for my condition.
& to strengthen the conception. by Plait-
-er on my back, & belly, with the same
directions that Dr wittie prescribed feb.
21 61: which with Gods blessing prevail
for a perfect recovery.

After I had received
my health &
strength again in this miraculous
manner being still at oswoldkirk
there happened a very great an Re-
-markable deliverance to me of an
other nature, but of as grand a
consequence to my being so much
as my well being. & the Infants in
my womb. About the May following
the business was this. I had bought
6 young steers, with some of the moneys
54 1662.
that my dear mother had given
me before her death which was 150l
for my own use. which steers I
intended for Mr Thorntons Draught
& in case I should die of that child
I made it my desire to Mr Thornton
that he would pay those monies
which was agreed upon by my brot.
Denton which set the price betwixt us
being 24l for the 6 steers, I allow
ing Mr Th. 4l- for the wintering them
sine marts. 61 till may. day. I say
he promised me to make a bond of
his own good will to my Mothers
Excecutores for the said money to be
paid: by him at the next Michaelmas. 61:
but it so happened that Mr Th. did draw
the bond for marts & not for micklemas
as he first intended.

which he was pleased to
ill manner from me. & fell very much
offended. so that I was much troubled
as his displeasure in that kind & could
not refrain from weeping. at that
incident which I intended for his good
should turn to evil betwixt us.
but so it pleased god to suffer Satan to
Tempt (for my greater trial) that
Mr Th: was in a very high passion
against me for that particular mentioned
& that I should weep as he said on purpose
to shame him, which God knows it was not
for such end, but that there should be that
difference betwixt us upon so small a
cause.

his feet being big with child & in
a very sad condition for this accident
& holding him fast, Entreated him
for the Lords sake to take head what
he did to him self, & that it was the
devil which tempted him against him
-selfe & me to destroy us all. praying
him to take the goods I would never
own any of them rather then he
should be offended. & begged for Christ
sake to put away that evil design
& a las if he should doe it what would
become of his poor soul more worth
then the world. & of his Infant innocent
in me, who would be questioned for
his death & perhaps might suffer
57
there being no witnesses but God
& my own Innocency, still I begging
of God to hinder & prevent any thing
that might hurt him at last my ever
gracious father in heaven in mercy
was pleased to with draw my husband
passionate hand against him self &
us, & to appease his anger by degrees
but this unhappy accident wrought
so infinitely with grief upon my heart
That I fancied I saw the very blood
upon his pen knife, & had very near
gon to make me miscarry at that instant
but my merciful God did preserve
me at that very time from miscarriage
also, O what shall I render unto the Lord
for all his goodness declared unto me
weak worm unworthy to live upon
the earth, or have such infinite mercies
poured upon me. he heard my groanings
at this time also & delivered my husband
58
from his Evil intentions, & rash Act
against his weak creature his wife
& poor babe in my womb. I confess
my folly had deserved a great punishment
but what had it don that should have suff
-red with me. now lo the Lord God of
Hosts was at hand to deliver in sec
-ret & send help from above. theref
-ore praise. the great God on high &
render o my soul all that is within thee
to his holy name. that heard. & delivered
thee in thy deep distress. let not
this nor any of his great mercies be
forgotten by thee whilst thou lives
yet it pleased God that this mercy
should not be forgotten. he did I be
-leive) set a mark upon my sone
Roberts heart for a note of his deliverance
at that time, for when the Child was
borne. he had a very strange
59
Mark just upon his heart, of
sprinkles of blood, pure & perfectly
distinct round spots like as if it had
been sprinkled upon his skin, & the
white perfectly appearing betwixt them.
& in the midst thereof, as if it had
been cut with a knife a longish cut
In this form it continued for half
a year in its perfect colour, being
seen often times by my self. Mr Th.
my brother Denton. my 2 sisters, & sev
-erall others with the nurse & servants.
This changed into the shape of a perfect
heart all the spots being contracted
into one in that form. & colour. Then by
degrees, grew like a perfect T: of the sam
colour. & continued so, till the child
was near a year old. and then it
grew bluish, & by little & little it
went quite a way. and no appearance
thereof left of it.

This also must be imputed to the
goodness of God. who would not
leave such a remark of our offence
but gently to put us in mind of
our folly & provocation of his
wrath. I humbly offer my unfe
igned thanks & praise to his holy
name, which heard my humble
supplication in this particular
by removing this unkindly &
unusual remembrance which
caused grief at each sight
there of. but yet my Soul doe
not in the least measure prove
ungrateful for the many mercies
received at the hand of God; nor
bury them in forgetfulness, &
61
unworthy walking before him all
the days of thy life but set this
up as a Pillar of praise to his
majesty for ever. Praise the Lord
o my soul & for get not all his
benefits, which hath not turned a-
way his face from thy prayer, butt
granted thy Petitions.

After this sad accident befell me
at Oswoldkirke; I had beyond ex-
-pectation my strength & health
perfectly restored unto me, so that
I was able to walk to Newton
a bout May or Jun which was the time
of our first settlement into the house
; soon after Mr Thorntons business
about Nettletons Suite, called him to.
London.
62
to Prevent Nettleton from breaking
up an execution against his Estate
for a Dept of my fathers which Mr
Thornton had been advised by some
to enter into & to engage for, af
ter he had unfortunately taken up
-on him the Assignment of my uncle
maior norton of my fathers Estate
In Ireland which was to pay his
debts & Portions. A business which
I must clear, both my Dear Mother
& my self from. that we had no hand
in the least in it, to advise him there to
which we knew was no way suitable
neither to his Person nor Estate, being
of great trouble, & with out that which
my. Portion (being the pretence for it)
was undoubtedly safe & secured by
my fathers will, he having at that
time a lease of Land in Kirklingtn
63
in Possession for the payment of the
English Portion of 1500, & the will empowering
my husband for 1000l to be paid out
of Ireland in its due order.
but it so happened that he was advised
with out our knowledge or consent
to engage as formerly mentioned to Net
-leton for 900l Pay able out of his
own Estate in regard that he would not
take security out of Ireland & so
hotly prosecuted my husband that he
was forced to procure monies, & had
paid him the 900l & above, yet the bond not
being taken in he demanded 1000l
over. the statute was for, & when Mr Th
was at London, got by some unjust
means an Execution broke up, and
one morning sent his own man with
4 bailiffs to seize upon all our goods,
money, Plate & till he was satisfied

at first they demanded 800l then
to be paid. but at last they fell to
200l which they would have, or Plate
as much worth. This accident was
indeed very afflicting to me in that cond-
-ition big with child, also knowing
Mr th. went up to prevent the sam
it had well nigh gon near to have
caused me with grief to have miscarried
what for the unjustness thereof, &
disgrace that redounded to us in this
business; but as it pleased God
there was 100l of Mr Ths at that
time in the house newly come in, and
57l of my own which my d. mother
gave me. that stopped their mouths
at that present, or else it might have
proved far worse with me at that
present. when they might have
65
Taken away my bed from under me
& those quick goods my dear mo.
gave for my relief & children's
these men were very boisterous, &
rude threatening to take my Person
if not satisfied. Lo in what a
sad case was I then in. & but that it
pleased God to give me Relief I
had not escaped with my Life.
& by reason that I feared the neglect of
this business to fall out thus, it did
some what arm me with patience to
endure it better having thoughts
of it before. thus have I upon every
occasion & act of my life fresh cause
to speak good of the Lord, who though
he pleases to suffer men to afflict
me all manner of ways yet with the aff
liction he maketh a way to escape. &
does not permit more to be laid upon me
66.
these he gives me strength, & assista-
-nce to go through. therefore will I
give thanks unto his name & speak
of his praise in the Land of the Living
that hath not yet given me over to deat-
h & bonds. I humbly Trust in conf
-dence of these his mercies, that he will
make a way for me to Escape, &
will look upon my affliction &
Trouble. which I suffer from the unki-
-ndnese of my own friends & relations
of the flesh, giving me a double
Portion of Grace for that I am de-
-prived of the Portion & provision
of my father. by these unjust means
against my self & poor children
whose Portion & inheritance I trust
the Lord will be forever.
Remembr
my Dream of Nettletens Bailiff this morning before
they came. & my fall down the stairs when Celia
Danby fell & I helped her when Co. Covill was here.

After this, drawing near a month
of my delivery. it behoved me to
look with a more narrow search into
my soul & examine how things went
with me there. whose time of life might
very probably be very short. this
being now my seventh Child which
God had given me to conceive. I had
more strong apprehensions of a change
in regard it was, both my husbands
mother number. & my own. did more
feelingly work with me. therefore
as at all times death waits for us. yet
more usual it is for us to expect
at these strange & miraculous times
especially as they have been to me, more
then many. motives I had great plenty
to examine my own ways. by reason
of my sorrows I had came upon me
68
in the whole course of my life, &
of thankfulness to God for the daily
renewal of the same.

I found by sad experiences that the many
troubles had fallen upon me of this
world had diverted my stricter course
of walking with my God as he had
required at my hand. & that I had
many times broken those solemner
vows of Baptismal, & sacrament
-all to frequently. & too often by
negligence, worldly employments,
& wilful sins. so that I had great
impulses upon my heart. & desires to
renew this grand ordinance of God
& in true & unfeigned repentance, faith
hope & charity. to be maid a partaker
of this strengthening. this comforting
69
& confirming, holy Sacrament, which
my blessed Saviour left us as his
dearest pledge of his love. who laid
down his Life for sinners, that sinned
not that became poor that We might
through his grace be made rich.

I had not the happy opportunity to receive
this communion but once since my dr
mothers death although my soul had
much longed for it. by reason that the
ministers on this side had not given
given the same for many years during
the wars. So that I called to mind that holy
man Dr Samwaies which did last give
the sacrament to my blessed mother. &
I desired his company to Newton
who accordingly did come, & bring
my Cossn Ben. Browne along. when
we with Mr Th. my neece Anne Danby
70
& divers others did receive the pledge
I hope of our Salvation from his hand
by which I was much comforted, &
helped, enlivened, & quickened from
that black veil & cloud of sine
that did seem to quite extinguished
the hope of my eternal salvation

This most excellent & spiritual
mercy was not the least. but greatest
I apprehended to receive from God, fare
surpassing all temporals inasmuch
as Eternity does this finite beings
O that my heart would break in
pieces at the joyful remembrance of this
renewing mercy wherein God was pleased
to be come my reconciled God in & through
my dear Redeemers blood shed upon
the Cross.

And that my soul might forever
sing unto him Hallelujahs of praise
in heaven, with Angels & Arch
Angels .& all the Host of Heaven
I here prostrate my Soul before the
Throne of Grace.that hath showed me his
poor weak handmaid shush such
hopes, such mercies, & opportunities
or making my calling & election sure
And he will for his grace sake full
-fill in me the full Perfection of Glory
with him in heaven. to behold the holy
Trinity with Joy, & doe his will
perfectly there. which I cannot by reason
of my many frailties & sins doe in this
world, but weakly & imperfectly.
but o that I might be freed from this pour
of sine that it may not get domain over
me to dishonour the name of my God.
Amen.

72 1662
After I had obtained this
mercy & satisfaction to my poor
Soul of partaking of the Lords
Supper, & in the best manner & me
asure I could prepared my self
to be in readiness when my God
should call for me out of this mi
-serable world. I thought it my
duty also in the next place to
settle those things which conseild my Childre
-ns Provision for the future, both
in respect of what was given to
me by goodness of my dear mother
to dispose of as I should see fit
to such children as I knew best
deserving at my death, or otherwise
as Also to be a means to Mr Thorn
that he would make a firm settleme
-nt of what was agreed upon,
73
of his Estate with my mother in
and by the Articles drawn betwixt them
before my Marriage. which till then
was not perfectly don, but that in
case of my death it might not only
breed scruples, but as it might
happen, might be altogether dispo-
-sed from my own poor Children
to the Children of any other wife.
the sense where of did somewhat
trouble me. how I should find out
one that would deal impartially as
concerning the faithful stating of
this business, & to doe right to all
parties. being in a strait what to doe
& having joined in a fine to cut of the
first settlement & so brought my self
into a worse condition, till a better was
made.

I found that the often experience
of the failing of the things of this
life had brought our Estate into
an uncertain condition & daily
our Estate was lessened and those
monies left me by my dear mother
was laid out for Mr Thorntons
use with which I could have helped
my daughters, to the sum of 300l
so being gon. & the Estate of Burn
Park sold and those monies
disbursed for Debts, together with
my own 1000l Portion which was
settled by Articles. & bond before
marriage upon my self & children
Also was to be set over for debts &
all to clear Mr Thorntons Engagements
which I was no way guilty of drawing
him into. these things did much
75
concern me at this time. & me made with
fear look upon the sad & Ruinous condition
I was like to leave indeed all my poor
Children in by reason of this unsettlement
either for Provision of maintenance
or Portions. also looking on my self in
a dieing condition being in every Child
birth so extremely weak & hazarde
Nor had I in this Place none of my
own relations to advise with or be assisted
by I thought my case very sad, as also
I was very unwilling to disclose any of
these secrets concerning our Estate to others
I poured out my complaints & cause
before the great God of Heaven in whose
power it was alone to give us help
& assistance, both as to the enabling us to
pay off his Just debts as also to give me
a satisfaction in the settlement of Mr Th.
upon my Children for provision & therefore to him
for relief a lone I on my bended knees
76
1662
I humbly cast my self at the
Throne of Grace, who had ever bin
my guide & director in all my ways
& in every grand action of my Life
when I made my earnest addresses.
to him; so my petitions & requests
to the Almighty was that he would
direct me in this greatest Temporal
concerns for the good of my Children
that he would please to put in to my
heart what course to take & to
direct me to such means as should
be for this very end, that I might go
to my grave in Peace; having seen
the merciful Provision of God, in a
hopeful way settled for their future
Provision & maintenance. in this
world. And immediately after this
prayer to God, there came into my
77
thoughts my Co. Colvill whom was
a very able Person. & a faithful friend
to us. he I sent for, & by the blessing
of God was suffered to make such a
comfortable settlement, through
Mr Thorntons love & great affection
to me & mine, that I hope it will
endure for the satisfaction of all just
Person in justice & equity making
provision for the younger Children
of so well as the son & heir (if God
did please to give me one).

which was don to my great content
& satisfaction that I might more Joy-
-fully leave this world, then to have
gon out unworthily to the fruit of my
own womb. who had given away all
my Portion from them & theirs. never
to have been better for 2500l of my
own Portion, having
78
given it to my husband & for his
debts & use. so that had I not inde
-vered some part of satisfaction
for the Children that God had given me
I had been unworthy to have
borne the name of a mother which
had left them in an unsettled cond-
-ition for all that fortune which God
& my own Parents had mercifully
given me. So that although it may
be said I have don less for them
then my own fortune considered.
yet it is sufficient that I have don
what I can, in respect of your fathers
Estate laden with many burdens
& what I could for the satisfaction
of my own Conscience. And blessed
be God who gave me space, and
opportunity for the same.

Almighty God the wise disposer
of all good things both of heaven
& earth. who sees what & how much
of the comforts of this mortal life is
fit for us to enjoy in this Earth. did
at last give me such a mercy & dear
comfort after all the several afflictions
I had passed: As I no ways could hope
for or expect. making me a Joyful
mother of a sweet Son. borne at
full time. though with hard travail
& great peril to my life.

I Was delivered of my Son Robert
Thornton upon Friday the 19th of Sept
-ember 1662 borne at Easte Newton
my husbands Chief house wher being
the first child that ever I bore at his
house. he was borne betwixt the hours
of 8 & 9 a clock at night having
been in Labour since the night before
till that time. he was my seventh
Child.

But as though this mercy should
not go alone, without its rememb
-rancer or severe monitor to my
unbridled passion of Joy. & that it may
prove the more cautious to me. not to
set my Affection too much on things
below.

It pleased the great God to lay on
me his weak handmaid an excee
-ding violent weakness. beginning
a little after my child was borne.
by a most Terrible flux of blood
after his birth. with such excessive
floods all that night that it was
terrible to those about me. & brought
me into a most desperate condition
without hopes of life. spirits. soul
& strength seemed all to be gon from
me. & my husband & friends had taken
their farewell. In this most de-
-plorable condition I lay several
81.
hours together. not being able to
utter one word. all the means they
could doe in such a fright was don
but did not avail.

It pleased my gracious Lord at last
to bring into my remembrance a powder
which I had formerly by his blessing don
good to many in the like kind. so I got
out the name of it to my Lady Yorke
with much ado to be heard for my weak
nesse was such. but after she had
given me some of it I found the good
effect of it thorough the tender mercy
of my Redeemer. who healed all that
came to him. by it he helped me. some
what so that the flux was a little stayed
by degrees. till Dr Wittie was come.
so upon the same blessing & use of the
means I was spared at that time
but brought so weak that the remainder
82
lasted till Candlemas after by
fits upon me.

But oh o Lord wherefore are thy
miraculous mercies thus continued
to so vile a worm as my self.
Doubtless to set forth thine Almi
-ghty Power, Glory. & Infinite
Perfection. that can Raise from
death, & bring to the Grave in a
- moment.

O Just and dear God I humbly
& prostrate lie at thy footstool
of mercy giving thy divine majesty
All possible thanks power praise
dominion, Glory, & what ever can
be by the tongue of men & Angels
given to thy most Glorious Majesty
King of Kings & lords. the only
giver & preserver of my soul.
83
And body. the one from spiritual
the other from temporal. & Eternal
Death. Let not glorious Trinity
this death joined with the others I
have been preserved from be forgotten
but seal it with Indelible characters
of remembrance upon my soul &
body. how can I sufficiently set forth
thy praise that cannot express your mercies.
O Let the holy spirit inspire my heart
to utter forth thy holiness goodness
loving kindness of the Lord and that
for ever. in this life & that which is
to come

doe not forget o my sad soul what
the Lord hath done for thee times without
number o let me live to magnify thy
name day & night & let this be an
argument of thy favour to me. for
Jesus Christs sake Amen.

Yea the Lord god had pity upon
my distress & gave me after this
a competency of health & strength
to be able to give my Child suck.
which by his blessing I did till Robin
was about 2 years old. he contineu
-uing very health full & strong.
so that my sorrows much abated.
thus may I sing a new song of thanks
giving & praise to God on hie . who
had compassion upon the vilest of his
creatures .with my mouth will I
ever set forth his praise and tell of
his marvellous greatness. from day
to day. Let this stand as a Pillar of
gratitude which I erect for all the deli
-verances I have had & my Children
both in soul & body. the living the living
he shall praise thee in heaven & Earth. by

My Son Robert was baptised on
Saturday the 20th of September: 1662
by Mr Luckock at Newton.
his Godfather & Godmother were my
Lady Cholmely: Dr wittie: & Mr
Thornton for my Nephew Best:

The God of All consolations & comforts
preserve his life & health. with the opor
-tunitys of virtuous & holy Education
that he may be the instrument of great
Glory to God comfort to his Parents
& relations. & for the building up in
Righteousness & holiness his fathers
Family. to Posterity for many genera
-tions. And at the end of his life. he may
receive the Comfort of a sanctified old
Age. with a Crown of Glory to praise
his Redeemer & mine for ever & ever:
finding what the goodness of God has been to
me in giving me the request of my heart &
86 63
being received by
& from the mercy
of a gracious father who hath
at length bestowed on me his
handmaid this hopes of the continuance
of my Memory: by a blessed son
of my womb. having obtained
him from god by the fervent prayers
& tears of a poor mother:
To thee o Lord I dedicate this
Child the son of my womb.
Let him be ever in thy sight for
good. & establish thy covenant
with him made to Abraham & the faithful
As thou hast given him the sign of it
so most mighty . give him the true
grace. that he may be established
before thee both here & hereafter
That for Jesus Christ our Ever blessed
saviour :& Redeemer. Amen. Amen.

After that Robin was 2 years old
Mr Thornton went to London. where
he had a great deliverance from
a flood of waters in his coming home.
great are our obligations to God Alm-
-ighty for our lives many times given
us. which affords me new occasions of
glorifying the Eternal Lord. & therefore
with my Tongue will I ever be setting
out his praise.

who brought us safely to meet again
with Joy to enjoy these temporal comf-
-orts of each others Love. this is the
goodness of our God.

Oh that we might make a right use
of these temporals that we finally lose
not the hopes of his eternal mercies
for ever in heaven . which his saints &
Angels doe now inherit.
Amen.

It pleased my gracious God. to
give me a new hopes of a com
-fort (although these mercies are
accompanied with thorny cares & troubles
I was continued in much health &
strength all a long while I was
with child till a bout a fortnight
before I was delivered. when the pangs
of child bearing was oft remembering me
but it was the good pleasure of
God to give me a safe. though very
sharpe delivery. after a day & a
nights travail. I was happy in a
goodly strong sweet Child. A
daughter: yet after I came in
bed I had a great flood as of
Robin which did well nigh carry me
away. but by the mercy of God
I had a remedy ready from Dr wity
89
1665
& so prevented. by Gods blessing
the extremity from falling on me.
And I had a better recovery of this
Child then ever of any. for ever
blessed be. the Incomprehensible
Lord God of Pity & compassion to
spare me a wretch. and did give
me the blessing of the breasts also. add
=ing holy strength to my self & Infant.
O my Lord God accept I beseech thee
the humble addresses of my Soul &
body & give me a thankful heart
to rejoice in thy salvation. non but
thou a lone o father of mercies could
raise me up. my sins had prevailed but
thy infinite clemency & mercifulness
is above thy Judgments. o Lord
therefore will I magnify thy name for
Ever. Amen.

My Sweet Child Joyce which was
my Eith Eight child was borne on
Saturday a bout 4 a clock in the
after noone. on September the 23th
1665 and she was baptised on the
28th day:

Her Godfather was my Lord Frechail
by Mr Comber who stood for him.
Mr Rich. Ledgard. Mrs Graham
& Mrs Cholmely.

It pleased my gracious Father still
to give me much comfort in the nursing
of this child having received more
strength to enable me for that service
she growing strong & thriving well
through the blessing of God upon my
endeavours, to perform this duty
therefore doe I praise the great God
of my Life. for this temporal mercy
also for all good comes from him.

But peradventure I might be too
much lifted up by this mercy. & there
-fore it seemed good to the most wise
providence of our Creator. to lay a
very sad affliction upon Mr Thornton
& my self in a most dangerous sickness
seizing upon him as he was at Yorke
about the 16th of novemb.r 1665
when he could not come home because
of the violency of cold, & the prevailing
distemper growing more upon him in his
Journey. so that he was forced to be at Stersby
my sister Cholmleys house.

For three days that grievous distemper
of the Palsy. convulsions. and fever
was so high upon him that notwithstanding
all remedies that could be used by Dr wittie
that he was not capable to assist himself
or indeed some times of what others did for
him. it seeming to all his friends there present
that he was more like to die. then hopes of
life.

The sudden news of his condition
being made known to me when I expec
-ted to have received him home in health
did so surprise my spirits, that I was broug
-ht into such a passion of sorrow & grief,
g in to greater weakness of body. then
I had ever known in all my former weak
-nesses and troubles .in so short a space.
so that I did sympathise very deeply in his
in his sufferings . being deprived of doing
my Duty in his extremity. or be helpful
to my self. nor had I any hopes of the
sparing of either of our lives as to outward
appearance . but only in the great & mirac
-ulous, mercy of the fountain of Goodness
The Almighty God of heaven. who turneth
man to destruction. & saith return again
from the grave the children of men.
nor had I any comfort, or friend that could
assist me in my sorrows at that time. save
what I had. in. & received by the prayers and
93
Assistance, advice, & counsel of Mr Comber
whom my gracious God had given me at
that time to be a means to support my
fainting spirits under this most sad afflicti
-on. when my father & mother forsook
me (by death) the Lord taketh me up. &
supports me from falling totally. though
he suffers me to be brought very low. & that
justly for my transgressions & offences.
yet hath he not given me over to death
or despair.

Look when we were the nearest death behold
the goodness of God was entreated for us to
restore both our lives and let me ever return
him the glory of his power. & the return of our
Prayers. be ascribed to his majesty. that imm-
-eadiatly gave us a hopes of recovery upon
our calling upon his name. for that every day
my husband did miraculously change, &
each day recovered so fast that it was a wonder
to all beholders. Oh what shall I say or doe
to set forth the infinite mercies & loving kindness
of the Lord our God:

who still in the midst of Judgment
remembers mercies. & shows his compassion
upon his poor Creatures.
O Lord God, thou King of Glory & Power
just are thy judgments .whether spiritual
or Temporal. thou has chastised me very
sore .& all thy storms are gon over my
head. but surely I have offended & don a
-miss .either in negligence, or remissness
of duties or some other way or other forget
-ing thy former. deliverances therefore hast
thou seen fit to correct me in this manner.
But yet give me grace to have a sanctified
use of this affliction upon our bodies .&
grant that this may may be for the good &
profit of our souls .& that I may say it is
good for me to be afflicted. grant that I may
receive instruction. to my soul. and that thy
loving correction may make me humble.
& thankful. I here from the bottom of my
unfeigned soul & heart. lift up my voice
95
to adore, & praise, & magnify thy great
& glorious name. thou o Lord art holy
thou art just, wise, Omnipotent, Almighty
and infinitely full of compassions towards
thy frail creatures. we sin & thou chasti-
-seth us into obedience. if thy mercy will
not move, thy rod must correct. O Let
us not forget, or slight this deliverance
to us both. but more especially let it
never slip out of my mind but write this
upon the table of my heart. that the Lord has
added added this new Life of my husbands
at my humble request, & given us both
fresh and eminent cause of gratitude to
his majesty. to thee o Lord, holy Trinity
doe I dedicate my soul & all its faculties
to be a sacrifice of praise. Let me not fall
into any sins to offend or displease so loving
a father. who did not cast me a way in
distress. Blessed be the Name of our Redeemer
by whose intercession .& passion I obtain this
mercy. even for ever & ever. Amen.

While I am in this body of death
I find by sad experience. that as my days
increase so will sin grow up too rife in
these corruptions. I have tasted of the great
& unlimited mercies & clemency of the
Great God of Heaven. the Lord most
High. And like wise been under manifold
trials. sorrows, troubles, & Afflictions
both as to spirit & body.

But as when the hand of God is upon us we
are apt to be more discomfited & sad. so shod
I, and doe desire to make it my utmost
endeavour to inquire what is it that God
aims at by all his providences & dealings.
I find my heart to apt to forget what a
low condition I was brought into by sickness
& sathan. either as to Mr Thorntos or my
own trials. And peradventure hath not
rendered him that due praise for all our Exceding
deliverances that he hath vouchsafed to me in
particular or him.
93
or sure for some other punishment of
my negligent soul is the Lords hand stretched
out still, and which by a late cross he hath
showed his anger against me. shall I receive
good at the hand of God & not render him the
Glory. or shall I receive corrections from the same
hand. and still be insensible there of God
forbid. why or wherefore he thus deals
with me.

It was his infinite goodness in giving me
this sweet Infant, in giving her the
blessed opportunity of holy Baptism. and
is the mercy the less in that he has pleased
to deprive me of its enjoyment any longer,
or by the prevention of Actual sin in her.
O no: I humbly acknowledge all these his
mercies .& give him the glory due to him therein
my sins was ripe for punishment. & he
pleased thus it should be. to teach me by
his Rod & staff to approve myself an
obedient child to so good. so great, so loving
a father.

I dare not. I will not repine at this
most gracious chastisement. it may seem
a little troublesome to part with my sucking
Child from my breast for the present. & surely
the hand of God is in it for my punishment.
but good is the the will of the Lord. is it not good
in as much as he hath spared me still to
repent, who is the vilest the meanest. & un-
-profitable worm upon earth. and given me
still the lives & comforts of my dear husband
& 3 children.

As to Temporals this is exceedingly much more
then I could have expected. & therefore will
I praise the Lord our God:

But for spiritual mercies. such have those
bin in an infinite measure showered down on
my head that I am not able to enumerate
nor tell them neither can my tongue or heart ex-
-presse them.

But to the glory of thy holy name doe I ascribe
the honour of my creation, the inestimable mercy
99 65
of giving Redemption to the world by thy
blessed Son. my saviour. & thou o holy spirit
the god of all consolations & comforts.
Holy, be the Lord most high, & glory to
his Eternal name that hath not taken
the hopes of salvation from me.

And great Lord as thou hast pleased to
teach me by Afflictions, oh give me the
sanctification thereof that I may spend no
more this small inch of time unprofitably
which thou givest me in this life. but by all means
to make it my business to Glory fie thy
name by a true and unfeigned repentance
such as may work throughly to the gaining thy
favour: & faith to believe in thy mercies
that thou hast a love for my soul & desire
not the death of a sinner, but rather that we
should be converted & live.

my dear Child Joyce fell very sick upon
Sunday 20th of Jan. 1665 as we thought of a
cold which struck in many Red spots which was
100
1665.
over her face & body after which she
did much cry & moan
with sickness.
but we used what means could be to so
young a Child. yet nothing was effectual
being the pleasure of God to take her out of
this miserable world.

She continued with some intermissions till thursday
after. when it was past hopes. of her recovery
and about betwixt one & 2 a clock rings
at noon of on friday the 26th of Jan. 65
it pleased God to free her from all pain
by taking her to his. mercy. where she
sweetly fell asleep.

She was buried at Stonegrave the next
day by Mr Comber: who preached A
funeral sermon.

The Lord my life prepare me for this change
& dissolution. that then I may see that God face to
face which I doe now believe, & put my trust
& confidence in. & for ever peace from sin &
sorrow. & this for his sake that suffered for sin &
101
1666.
sinned not. the holy one of God.
O let me not in the interim be unmindful of
his hand by these corrections. but may be
delivered from the Jaws of Eternal death
Amen.

It pleased God to deliver my daughter
Alice from a very dangerous & violent
illness coming on in her sleep.
when she lay in bed with me. who was
suddenly wakened in a great fright with the
noise of her who almost choked
& the breath stopped with undigested fish.
(Turbot) that was not fresh she eat the night
before, but praised be the Lord upon my
help, she did recover, & other things given
this eased her after vomiting. blessed be
the most gracious mercy of my God for
Ever that hath raised this child up from
death very often even from a young Child
being often in sounds upon the breeding
of her teeth: this fit was June 13th 1665
at Newton. when she was ill she was even
Ravished with the glorious sight.

After the drinking of Scarbrough
waters Mr Thornton sent for me to Yorke about
business with my Lord Frechuill; in which
Journey I thought I received harm,
being lately conceived before, as
Dr wittie did apprehend; & it, together
with a grief that befell me upon my ret
return home by: W. T.
about by Settlement
of Provision for my Children's main-
-tenance & Portions. which was undone
without my consent or knowledge. by
some persuasion of Mr Th. before:

I fell into a very sad & desperate
condition, through the breaks, & excess
of floods perpetually flowing which began
upon Saturday the 6th of August: 66
being at that time about 8 weeks conceived
with Child. the violency thereof continued
a long time after Dr wittie was with me 3 days
so that it put him to his utmost art for my
preservation but it did abate a little
& intermitted upon the several medicines
he gave & left me in a hopeful way.
103
of recovery but told us till about
a quarter I might not expect a full recovery
when it was likely the fruit should have
bin quick child if I had gon to my time.
which I found to be true, for I continued
with floods by intermission a day. or 2
and then returned, till the later end of
october notwithstanding all good things
I had to prevent it. the chiefest remedy
I found good in was bole Armoniac
in fine powder half a spoonful at a
time with a little draught of claret
wine burned with Cinnamon & loaf sugar
taken as often as extremity required.
the total weaknesses & disability of nature
& body was so great by loss of blood. that
it was expected I should have fallen into
a deep consumption. I did indeed contin-eu
exceeding feeble & weak till a bout Jane
uary After, when through the mighty Power
& wonderful mercy and goodness of God
he was pleased to free me & give strength
to the weak handmaid of the Lord for which I
shall ever adore & magnify the Almighty
Father of mercies which raised me up again
from the Gates of Death. Blessed be his
name for Ever And for ever. Amen.

About the 2d of September 66 began
the great fire in London which in 4 days
time consumed 13200 houses, 89
Churches, &c.

Upon the 29th day of Sept.ber began
my Daughter Kate Thornton with
a violent & extreme pain in the
back & head with such skrikes & torment
that she was deprived of Reason, sleep &
eating any food. so continued for 3
days to my great affliction what this
distemper would be, at last the smallpox
appeared & broke out in a great abundance
all over, & in her ungedablenesse stroke
in again, so that to save her life my Brother
Portington gave her much cordials, & thus
it pleased God she was in hopes of life
but was in very great danger to lose her eye
sight. she was all over in a scurf in the
face which ran into one another. but I bless
God she was past danger of death & they
began to dry. although she was very sore
all over the body. her extremity was so
great in crying night & day that I was fain
to be removed though very weak as before
into the scarlet chamber for want of rest.

but blessed be our gracious God through
his infinite mercy directing to good help &
means & prospering the same she was lately
healed & recovered again .Hannah Ableson
& mary Cotes was her keepers & about
november was able to go abroad in the house.
but lost her fair head of hair that was on her
head. I praise my God that he was entreated by
by me to spare her life. oh that she may live
to his Glory for Christs sake & give me a
thankful heart to commemorate his mercies Amen.

It pleased God to visit my dear Brother
John Wandesford at London 10th his last
sickness being an Ague. a joined with fits
of the stone. & some extremities of sickness
which about the 2d day of December deprived
him of his life, for several years before
he had laid under the most sad & afflicting
hand of God by reason of the want of the
use of his understanding several times
yet having abundance of intervals. in which
time he was very Religiously disposed &
constant in duties with a conscience
to spend
his days holily & uprightly, and in great
penitency for any thing don in his weakness
although he never did any creature willing harm
about half a year before his death he was
more strict in his duties. saying that he should
not live long

So that he prepared for his dissolution every
day & that morning he departed kneeled in
bed & most devoutly prayed to God &
commended his soul to his Creator; &
after commending his dearest love to
me & Mr Thornton, he drew shorter each
minute & so sweetly fell a sleep in the Lord.
he was buried in the Parish Church where
he died at Hodghdon. & Mr Comber was
by providence there who preached a funeral
sermon for the instruction of living.
he died December 2d & was buried the 3d 1666

About this christmas 1666 my Cousin
will.m Norton was murdered inhumanely
at London.

The 5th of January 1667 my dear
Robin Thornton began his sickness of the
smallpox being very ill & weak for a
2 days & the 7, 8, 9 days he was in
great danger of death they not coming
well out till the tenth day. on which day he
lost his sight by them who was come out
very much & was great ones, on the 14th his
fever & disease was at the height.

About 15th he began to alter for
the better so that a change was discerned.
17 he began to see again. 18th he perfec-tly
Recovered his sight, & recovered very
fast. for which I most humbly bless &
glorify our gracious God with all my soul
and magnify his mercies to me in the de-
-liverance of this my dear & sweet
Child from death & giving him as a bles-
-sing to his father & mother & not quen
-ching my cole in this Family. O praise
the Lord O: my soul & forget not this
his favour to thee. for ever Amen.

24th Robin first got up & on his feet
& was perfectly well uell growing daily strong
& was not disfigured at all with the Small
Pox. only he never since recovered his
sweet & beautiful favour & pure
colour in his cheeks. but his face drew
longer then before. nor did his hair
come off at all having but few in
his head but the most was in his face.
he wanted 9 Months, of being five
years old & some odd days.

It pleased God that as soon as my Son
Robin was well to visit my poor
Nally which first began on January 18
in another dangerous fit in her sleep
which wakened me in much fright & she
was almost choked with phlegm. & made
her exceeding sick before she could cast
being black in the face with extremity
but blessed be the lord after a vomit or
two she did recover although it did
much weaken her. praised be the Lord of
of our salvation for her deliverance. Amen.

About the 25th of January 1667 Nally took
Physic to prevent the smallpox & she
fell to be ill. in pain of the head & back
26th she was very sick & continued the
27 & 28 till the smallpox came out
being these 2 days in a cold Sweat & in
danger of death. the 29th my poor Nally
having laid very patiently all the time
before though great hazard of life when
there was little hopes because they had not
not come well out being in a Sweat all
that time that hindered them from appearing
109 1667
but on the 26th it pleased the most good
& gracious God did begin to give better
hopes the Pox coming well out, & she in
a warmer temper was not so sick. so that
by mercy we hoped for her recovery.
The 31th she fell blind & had intermiting
till the 5th of february being exceeding dange-
-rous in her throat & could not swallow
well till the 6th of february & being very sore
& much pained by the Pox therein & her
strait throat. getting very little sleep
till the 3d of february when she began to sleep
the 4th her eyes began to unclose. the 5th she
did see perfectly & they began to blacken
& die ripe. & her throat was pretty well
her fever did abate 8 she began to be
pretty well & strong. the 18th Nally rose out
of her bed and recover very fast grow-ing
strong by degrees. she had very many
& was full over her face & the hair came
all off. Oh that our souls, my mind & ♥
may for ever give glory to the great God of Heaven
& Earth. o sing praises to the Eternal King
which has given me my Children's life restoring
them from many deaths. o Lord accept my
grateful acknowledgment that we might live
to his Glory & hon.or for ever & Ever. Amen.

My brother Dentons Son John was
fallen into great extremity beginning
on Jan the 25th upon taking of Physic
which did not work kindly & so continued
the 27, 28, 29th being deprived of his
understanding & violent pain till about
about the 29 getting no sleep & in a high
fever & great danger of death, but
about 4 a clock in the morning he began
to be sencable & his use of understan
-ing returned, when the smallpox did
appear. but he had very few of them
& recovered very fast. blessed be God.

The 8th of April Nally had a Pearl
on her Eye after the smallpox which did
endanger her Lose of the Sight of that
Eye. but by waters, & medicines, it
was worn off & she recovered it well
about the 30th of April 1667.
blessed be God for the least & greatest
testimonies of his goodness to me &
mim mine. that I may set forth his praise
for ever more Amen.

Kate Thornton had a deliverance
from being choked with swallowing a pin
& got cross her throat at St nicholas
in the year 1659 when I was a means by
Gods blessing to save her life by putting
My finger in her mouth & thrusting the pin
side way & got it out of her throat.
for which I humbly praise God in this her
preservation from being destroyed by her
own folly.

About the year that Kate Thornton
was 10 years old. she was playing in the
Corn barn at Newton & swinging on
a Rope that hung across. from which she got so
high & cruel a fall by the boys her cousins
flinging her that she fell down with a great
force & was taken up dead. hanging like
a Calf being with black in the face &
not taking breath a long time which put
me into a grievous fright. till at last
it pleased God in much mercy to restore
her life & after half an hour time
112
she began to breath & by degrees to
come to her self again. & was put in
to bed being Rubbed very sore. but did
not know any body in a long time & very
ill in her head with great pain. but
at length she was very well again
I most humbly praise and magnify
my gracious God & heavenly father
who in Judgement remembers mercy
& not cuts ^
of the lifes of my poor Child-
-ren suddenly, oh praise the Lord for
ever for all manner of his deliverances
to me & mine Amen.

It was the permission of God to let a sad
& dismal stroke fall heavy upon my
Brother Danbys family in the most horrid
& wilful murder of my dear & brave
nephew Thomas Danby Eldest son to my
Sister committed with the barbarous sir-
cumstances that could be done by one
Beridge a stranger to him. but comrades
to, Ogle, & Jenny which was then with him
& did not assist. & the pretence about
Ogles sword. but doubtless it was proved
a design against his innocent Life.

This was done upon him in London near
the Grays Inne, about the August.
in year 1667.

It pleased the goodness of my gracious
God to give me a weak & sick time
of breeding my 9th Child after that former
break in September. 66 & till about the 10th
of may 1667 when I did perceive my
self with quick Child I had no health.
but afterwards, for all the time I was
with child till near my time of delivery
I was as strong & well as ever of any
of my Children, being able to go to the
Church at Stongrave a full mile on
foot twice each sunday & back again
without very little weariness. I bless my
gracious loving father that gave my strength
& health restoring. great comfort to me
& my dear & loving husband, who all
this summer & spring was so well as he had
never bin since the first ill fit of Palsy
at Steersby. but we were in a constant course
of Physic with him by Dr witties order. &
towards september he followed it but when I
grew so big & near my time about Mick
le-mas.
114 1667.
he intermitted in my illness & so ret-urnd
to his relapsed condition haveing Dr wittie
wittie sent for several times for him. & so
through means by Gods blessing he was
restored to me again blessed be our mer-
cefull God of our salvation. for ever more
Amen. & Amen.

I fell into pangs of Labour about the
4th of november being very ill. & so con-
-tineued by fits all that week. then on
monday the 11 of november 1668 monday the 11 of november 1667
. I fell
into travail, and about the hours of 10
& 11 a clock at night I was delivered
but I was never in all my Life nearer
death by forcing the Child so violently
