by the midwife insomuch as the neighbours
did fear I should bin divided from the
waste downwards & the Rest of all my
body. which caused inexpressible torment
& a dislocation of the Reins of the back
for a long time. & excessive pain in the
spleen & mother arising both together
upon me in my Child bed.

but for ever magnified & praised be
the great & Glorious Lord God Almighty
who did not give me over to this death
but has miraculously. & wonderfully
preserved my life from destruction, &
when I was stepping into the grave even
this 10 times, nay seaventy times seven
times has turned my sorrow in to joy.
that no death has yet had the upper hand.
O love the Lord o my soul delight in him
thy life thy Joy, thy salvation & refuge.
I called on him in my distress & he de-
-livered me out of all my fear. the
guide of my Youth & my preserver forever
he gave me a goodly, strong & sweet
Son turning my pains in to hopes of
Joy. & gave me the blessing of breasts &
of the womb, o praise the Lord for Ever.

my daughter Nally was on this night the
11th of no. with fear & grief for me so sick
in my Labour that she was in much danger
but blessed be the Lord recovered again of
that illness the next day. november 12th 67

Christofer Thornton my 9th Child
was borne at newton, on monday
the 11th of november: 1667 betwixt
the hours of 10 & a 11 at night.
Baptised the 12th at newton. his
godfathers & godmother. Mrs Anne Danby
my brother John Denton & my brother
[T]imothy Portington.

After this comfort of my Child I
recovered something better & got my
milk, the child thriving mightily
well & grew strong. being a most
sweet lovely Child. but least my
♥ should be set too much in the satisf
action on any creature on Earth it
seemed good to the most infinitely wise
God to take him from me & I had appre
-hensions there of long before any did
see a change in him. & therefore with a
full resignation to his providence I
endeavoured to submit to part willingly
with my sweet Child to my.
117
1668
incomprehensibly dear & loving
father in Heaven. begging that his will
might be my will in life & death.
when he was about 14 days old my
pretty Child broke out in little red
spots like smallpox which was the red
gum & upon Cold gotten through an
accident they stroke inwardly. & he fell
into a great looseness, notwithstanding
all the means I could use, & it continued
on him for 4 days. when he was very
patient & quiet. & being a very strong
Child indured it with much struggling but
at Length it pleased his saviour &
mine to deliver him after a sick night
& day out of that misery, & he sweetly fell
asleep on sunday at night about 6. or
7 a clock at night being then the first of
December 1667 being 3 weeks old upon the
2d of december. he was Buried at Stongrave
on the 2d december. by Mr Comber. who did
preach his funeral Sermon. December 2d
1667.

After my Childs death. I fell
into a great & long continued
weakness, by the swelling of my milk
in the left breast which kitt last sucked.
& did so nip the head that I was in fear
of a gangrene, buand the extreme
pain, cast me into a fever. which to-
-gether with other griefs. & colds &
extreme violent pain of the Teeth
did bring me into that weakness that I
Could neither stand nor go for
Feb.
67
4 months. but was carried to bed
& from bed in a chair. but ever
blessed & magnified by the great &
Glorious name of the Lord most high
which bringeth me down to the gates of
Death & raiseth me up again times
without number. & might most Justly
taken me out of this life but letting
me see the follies of this life & many
changes we are incident to, that I might
prepare more Earnestly & long for
119
1668
those Lasting joys that never shall
have end. which he in his good time will
please to bring me to. for my saviour
Jesus Christs his sake Amen.

After which recovery of my health
I was very much in affliction about
my dear husbands illness & often
relapses into his former Palaticke
fits. which fell on him notwithstanding
all the many remedies was perpetually
used by Dr witties order, & with good
success. so that from ye
November 67 till
August 68 he had not missed one fort-
-night from a relapse or the degrees of
it insomuch that I never enjoyed any comt
fort in consideration of & fear of him
& his sufferings & least I should be de-
prived of my Joy & delight in this life
though I bless God he had intermissions
which supported him: after every use of Physic
& other things, & according to the earliness
of the time in beginning them the fits was longer
or shorter in continuance.

About the 20th of July 1668. I had
a very great & dangerous sickness
fell upon me in being my perfect health
& strength. upon the occasion of a sudden
grief & terror that I was seized upon
in my neece kitt Danbys chamber at
Newton when her maid Barbara Tod.
did impudently accuse me to
be
fore my
face of my Servant Henna
Ableson for telling her from one Mary
Breakes of several stories (which were
very great) lies & falsehoods against
my self, of such a nature as did
much unbecome any to hear & not
to have ouacquainted me with at the
first. which my maid did utterly deny
& cleared her self & me upon her
oath, but the other woman having a
spleen against her. did carry so un
-hansomly & unchristianly towards me
in her bitter aggravation & in false
accusing the Hon.or of some of the Persons
121 .
1668
of my family & that before her mistress
that I fell presently into a most great &
sad excess of weeping & lamentable
sorrow that it had like to have lost me
my life having only. God & my own
conscience to give me testimonies of
Comfort. being so falsely & abominably
abused for my Charity in relieving
those that came under my Roof & to
whom I had don no wrong. (& out of
whose mouths God making them instru-
-ents to my clearing) notwithstanding
there maliciousness both in my accusat
-ion. & their secret plots of conseal-
-ment till that other wicked woman was
gon from newton, & by that means did
spread her lies a broad at Richmond.
& the highest aggravation of injury in those
persons. that was don by my bosom's friend that
knew my Innocency all my days. but
why can I not with patience take the bitter
cup. out of my saviours hand. & for
his love. lay down my Life that
122
1668.
suffered many opprobrious scorns
& abuses from his Enemies. O my soul
bless thou the Lord that he will please
to give thee to suffer & go in such steps as
he him self has trodden out the path of
Life in. has he not preserved thee from the
Evils of sine. & all those enormous
Crimes the vile world now lies wallowing
in. & wilt thou not show thy gratitude
to thy Redeemer that gives thee share
in sufferings & not with the partakers of
these wickednesses let thy heart
rejoice in his salvation. & that thy design
was very much desirous to advance
his Glory, all though Satan would
blemish those that he has no part in, yet
thy hope is in God who has redeemed thee
from all sin & wickedness, & given thee a
stay & support in all thy Anguish of
spirit. & preservation from the designs
of those who would, & did cruelly de-
-vour thy honour as much as in them
laid.

And lo when I was yet scarcely recovered
of my weakness from this grief & had
kept my bed 14 days. it pleased God
in his infinite and abundant mercy &
goodness to begin to restore that most
valued Jewel by me. (& which was endeavoured
to be wronged, (my good name). by the
coming of my dear Aunt over to
newton. who had heard the vile reports
blazed abroad by mary Breaks & lies
against my Innocent Soul this woman
full of deep dissembling & hipocricey-
- who could not prevail with her design up
-pon the Person of Mr Comber to have drawn
him for marriage. & failing of that end
did prevented her plausible carriage into
an inveterate malice & hatred. both against
him & my self, which having discovered that
it was Mr Combers desires to obtain my.
Daughter Alice in marriage, & that
he was
made use on to assist us in the Drawing of
settlements & writings for Mr Thorntons
Estate on my Children which I was had
good cause to see don, in regard of Mr
Thornton & my own dieing
condition
124
1668.
from hence I say this woman takes occasion
to pervert the most innocent actions in
the world, & such as was most Just &
honest, for the preservation of my Poor
family & Children from Ruin. I finding
a daily decay, & great weakness of body
& mind was very solicitous to to get this
don before our Deaths, which I may well appeal
to God cost me great sorrow & pains &
trouble. being of so great concernment, before
and in the Transaction of all these businesses
And this poor Gentleman. no small pains
trouble & care till it was finished, which
was don with the consent & knowledge of my
Husbands brother denton, a wise & prudent
man assisting us in the prosecution of these
designs &, has since bin a means of mine
& his Just vindication ofering of from any
of those wicked untruths forged against
us by this mary Breaks; whose lies had
my neeces Danbys Charity extended so far
to me as discovered before the womans going
from newton. I might turned them on the
Raiser's own head & there mischiefs on their
own hate, before Satan's
125
1668.
Instruments had divulged them to the
Infinite dishonour of God, & his poor
mean servants; but as my intentions was
Cordially good, so God would not suffer me to
perish, but took the matter into his own hand
to stop the mouths of my adversaries and
when I wanted relief in his providence sent
my dear Aunt to acquaint me, & so gave
me such favour in her Eyes & the rest of my
dear & Christian friends that I was had
by this
opportunity to make a Public cleansing &
vindication of all my innocent actions &
I hope gained such belief that the Lord has
appeared to stand on my side & therefore I
need not care what men can say against
me. but will give all possible Glory & praise
adoration & thanks to my Gracious God that
would not suffer me to depart this life with
any blot upon my person. but to approve my
continuance in the true faith of the Lord Jesus
Xst in which I was brought up, nor giving
occasion of blemish to that most noble Family
from whence I was descended. I acknowledge
the goodness of the Lord which hath several times
sent me Relief, in the company & comfortable
126
1668.
Assistances, praises, & sweet Religious
advices, & supports of my dear friends when
I was in deep distresses all which I take as
great encouragements to serve the Lord with
all my ♥ which his never failed his weak
& despised handmaid. & I know o Lord
that thou canst. & doest me good by this
heavy & sad affliction as well as all others
& teach me o Lord by this thy Rod &
scourge of wicked Tongues who seeketh
occasion to slay me & root out the rem-
-embrance from the Earth. & though they
curse yet bless thou, & behold the Anguish
of my soul for out of the deep have I
called, Lord save me I perish but still
put my trust in thee. o strengthen establish
& settle my ♥ in thy faith that neither life
nor death shall separate me from the Love
of God. And blessed be thy holy name that
preserved my dear Husbands love &
faithful affection to me all my life long
& that it was not in the power of man nor
Devil to shake or remove those faithful
& conjugal bonds & ties of Christian
127
1668.
& dearest & chaste affections betwixt
us making us both abhor the very mention
at all such vile abominations as this
world was too full of in all places but
where by Grace of our good god whom we
serve night & day has lived in a holy &
chaste bond of wedlock this above this
16 years. having this to comfort our
♥s that we are undefiled servants. enduring
to fallow Christ in the Regeneration that
we might Reign with him in Glory.
Oh that my soul may forever be thankful
to the most high God that had regard to his
poor & humble handmaid. what am I
o Lord that should have the testimonies of thy
mercy. I will give thee the glory of thy
works. mercies & favours for ever; &
most humbly beg, on the account of my
Xsts Intercession that I may have the grace of
perseverance, & a truly thankful ♥ to
walk worthy of these inestimable mercies
& glorify thee in the midst of all my trials
and sufferings that makest me way to Escape
now Praise the Lord o my soul, & forget not
all his benefits. Amen. Amen

July 25th 1668. It pleased God to give
my dear Robin Thornton a great mercy
in his preservation & deliverance upon that
day. for his sister Kate & cousin willy
Denton was and himself was playing
in the Hay Laith at newton upon the mow
and standing in the window about 4 yards
high from the Earth. he fell out of it into
the lane .& was very near with his head
to a great stone which if he had lighted on
it with head it had killed him falling that height
so that the danger is very great. & ought
to be had in remembrance with gratitude
& hearty Thanks to the great God of Heaven
which sent his Angel to preserve my dear
Child from death or any other harm
save a lump on his face. The glorious
name of God be praised for his life
& the Preservations thereof from all casul
-ties of dangers sicknesses dislocation
& Evils. Giving him a great share of
understanding. wit. memory. a loving
affable nature & several other good
gifts tending to the better accomplish
ment.
129
1668.
of his Person with natural indowment
-ments. but exceedingly much more by the
name of the Lord our God be adored in
that he has bin pleased to begin some
dawning hopes of his Grace in his heart
which appears in his being afflicted with
his good instructions when given him.
& his desire to be informed of all things
conserning God, & several notions of the
fear of the Lord upon hearing his Judgments
with many Christian & epithetical expres
sions in the ways of Piety, all which are
motives of great Comfort to me his poor
mother who has taken notice of the great
mercy of my God that hath not despised the
prayers of his handmaid, but given me
a gracious answer to my humble supplic
-ation for this blessing I begged of the Lord
as Hannah did Samuel. & has dedicated him
to his service even all his days. humbly
craving the continuance of his favour. &
130
1668.
Grace upon my Son. endowing him
with all Christian virtues. with faith.
knowledge & true understanding. to
guide & direct him in his youth to
follow him & walk in his ways to be
his lives end. being preserved as much
as he shall see it fit for him from all
temporal Evils & finally from Eternal
sorrow & misery in the world to come.
Consigning this my dear Child as a
blessing to his family, comfort to his
weak mother, & an instrument of the
Glory of his Creator, in this life to
serve him in his generation in righteous=
enesse, & finally to praise him in Heaven
being the most humble Petition of his hand
-maide & that for the sole & lone sake of our der
saviour ye Lord Jesus Xst his holy & blessed
son. for his Passions sake Amen. & Amen.

It pleased God that I remained very ill
& weak after the second Alarm I had
given me of unnatural, unkind &
unjust dealing with me out of the Scarlet
Chamber which was to my Aunts great grief &
trouble to hear. & by which malicious repit
-ttion to her, & renewing the wounds a fresh
of calumnies. I fell into a very grievous
extremity of grief again. upon the 5th
of september. which so affected my soul that did
raise both the Spleen & mother in my
sides both together with much pain & trouble
& had I not bin held on my Sides by my dear
Cozen Christopher Norton & comforted by my
Aunts wise & discreet. & affectionate kindness,
I had undoubtedly perished with that heavy
load of ♥ grief & Sorrow, that such treatche
-rous practices of Subtlety & dissembling
should be the Ruin of my Life & that honour
which was unspotted in my life & conversation
but blessed be my Gracious God & father of all
mercies. which laid no more upon me then he did
give me strength to bear. & though I was
smitten by false tongues Joining with my
132
1668
Adversaries. yet he was pleased to find
out a way for me to escape at that time
also. And comforted me on each side by
my dear & loving husbands faithful
love to me which never in all his life had
the least ill thoughts of my Innocent
soul. but through some deep plots
to have raised their own ends in my
Ruin would by insinuations flatter him
as he said himself discovered there malice
& it set his ♥ against such. & did farther
both lament my condition condole the same
& took my part against all those vile
detractors & did order their turning out
of the house both by letter & threatenings.
O my soul forget not this great & eminent
mercy be forgotten by thee but had in
remembrance before him for ever, which uni=
=ted our faithful hearts to each other in
Cordial, loyal & conjugal love &
amity all our days since we were knit in the
band of holy wedlock. together.

And to this maine pillar of help &
comfort to support my fainting weak
body. I had given me through mercy the
cordial & entire affection & assistance of
my dearest Aunt norton whose candour
& goodness did extend its arms to pity
my distress & to whom I had imparted
my sorrows & distress. & she so ordered
this business in wisdom that she delivered
me from the pressures that then laid upon my
Injured Person. which almost pressed me
to the death. & added many circumstance
to my succour that I should not have had by
any other in the world. therefore will I praise
& bless the Lord with all my soul & mag-
-nifie his name for ever. who judged my
cause & pitied my great Calamities &
will I hope bring me out of the mire & pitt
they made for my soul setting my ♥ at some
liberty although this grief has pierced
me so deep that its effects will remain all my
days. that Satan's Instruments should thus be
134
1668.
out against me & be a cause to keep
a due sense on my soul to walk
humbly holy & continue faithful
to my lives end. which has bin very full
of all manner of troubles & sorrows
almost ever since I entered into the
married estate: but it teacheth me
to expect Happiness in no Condition
state nor place under heaven. & to
rejoice in Tribulation where my faith
is unshaked & tottering. better were it
for me to enter never so maimed into the
Joys of my Lord then to Enter into Hell
in pleasures & this worlds wealth & satt-
-isfaction. Therefore behold the Hand-
-maid of the Lord, be it unto me according
to thy word, give me my Crosses here, that
I may enjoy thee, in thy kingdom. for who
so doth not deny him self here, & take up
his X & follow him is not worthy of him.
& what is a moment of time to an
Eternity, to Everlasting pleasures at the Rig
-ht hand of God.

Whilst I am in this veil of tears
& shadow of death. I must not expect
no more comforts then will preserve me
from sinking. nor will I repine at the great
Lord of Heaven & Earths most infinitely
wise disposition, for he knows how to pro-
-pose & intermix Xs
with comforts.
Smiles with frowns to his servants here
as shall be the best for them. not as they shall
think fit, which are but of yesterday. but
himself who sees not as man sees. but has
all things in his omnipresent, & omnipotent
power, & shall tend most to his own Glory.

no sooner was my strength in part
recruited again after my dear Aunts
departure home & having bin so weak that
I kept my bed above a week. so beginning
to rejoice at my deliverance from the late ill
nesse both of the Plague of Slanderous
tongues & the faintings abated something
But the first day that I did Arise out of my
bed. I had that news of my dear
136
1668.
Husbands falling sick at malton
brought to me by a letter to my Brother
denton. which did so suddenly surprise
my spirit that I fell to tremble exceed-
-ingly with great grief & fears upon
me for his safety & Life. Immediately
I sent for Dr wittie to go to Malton
& sent each day to see my dear &
only Joy & comfort, but my self so
much afflicted that I went presently to
bed & continued with the break & then I
was in danger of overflow. because of
my excessive sorrow. only the Lord did
support my Soul from sinking. on wedn-
-esday I sent my Brother Denton & Mr
Comber to my Joy at Malton. & longing
all the day to hear from him. & if I could
without loss of my poor & miserable life
I would have gon to have seen him myself
but my friends would not suffer me to make
an adventure thereof. but I stayed till
137.
1668.
Night when word was brought from Dr
wittie that I should be of good cheer for I
should have my dear heart home as well
to me as ever I had him in my life. so that
I did show up my hopes in God & power
out my Tears & Prayers in abundance that
night for the life, & health of dear Husband
with me if it did stand good with the will &
pleasure of our God. & got some little slumbers
though with fears & tremblings & sad & dis-
-mall dreams. when in the morning my bro.
-ther Denton came home. & very discreetly
prepared me with good advice & counsel to
entertain the Lords determinate will in all
things with patience & submission if the worst
should fall on me according to my fears.
but withal God Could raise him up again
if he see it fit. although my dear ♥
was very weak at which news I grew
very ill & the Lord pardon my weakness for
it with a renewing of my great sorrows for the
being fearful to be deprived of this my sole
delight in this world next under my good
God.

So betwixt hopes & fears I rested
till the next messenger came which was
about 4 a clock on Thursday in the
after noone. at which time I received the
news of the most Terrible loss that ever
woman lost in being deprived of my
Sweet & most
exceeding
dear Husband
that any creature could have. Such was
my extremity of Passion & trouble
upon this change that I was almost
changed into nothing & was ready
to go into the grave with him whom God
had Joined me to almost 17 years. great
are the sorrows of my ♥. and many
storms have gone over my. Soul
but this is a the Lords sharpest Arrow
that is gon out against me. now am I
left destitute of head. guide, help
or support in this world, tossed with all
the sorrows that a poor desolate widow
139
1668
can meet with all. the Lord has
broken in upon me like a mighty water
& poured on me his indignation. great
are my Calamities, my Cup is full of
complaints, bereft of A most dear
& tenderly loving husband that took part
with me in all sorrows. comforted me in
sadnesses. we walked together as dear
friends his love was mine, in his sickness
I was afflicted. now am I left of him
who was my Earthly delight. he being
gon to his Heavenly father. & left
me to lament his loss from me & my
poor fatherless Children. weak in
body. afflicted in spirit. low in my
Estate. losses of my dearest friends
& Relations & Children, & other comforts
as dear. & now to consummate my suff
-erings my Husband withdrawn. Oh
that my sorrows were weighed, & that the
Lord would pity my distress. I am
still thy Creature. by Creation. Redemption
Sanctification. preservation. from death
140
1668.
hell & the Grave. doe not despise
thy weak Handmaid. for thou didst
make me. I am thine oh give me
understanding & I shall live. take
me not a way out of the Land of the
living. but give me to serve the Lord
with a perfect heart & a willing mind.
hear the Rod & who hath sent it. is
there any Evil in a City & the Lord has
not don it. Is there not an appointed
time for man once to die. oh that I may
die daily & be with God in soul & spirit
loving him with all my soul & a perfect
♥. I must be still & know that it is God
that Ruleth in H. & Earth. the Lord is
his name. & his mercy is unto us. for he
did draw my Joy to his own self, &
fitted him for this dissolution. he remem
-bred the Lord in the days of his youth &
God was found of him.

I now doe want those good & Pious
prayers of him for me & mine which I have
enjoyed for many years, what can I
say, or what can I doe, each remembrance
brings in a fresh flood of tears. I water
my Couch. & widowed desolate bed. for
my self & Children. my think I hear
him say weep not for me but weep for
yourselves & Children. I was in the world
tormented with pains & crosses, losses &
sicknesses. troubles on every side. but
now I am Comforted in the bosom of my
Father & thy father whom I had a
desire to go to: now my Sorrows cant
ye not find no Relief to assuage the
violent Passion for this sad separation
is there no hope in the later End. what
if though my ♥ thou are deprived
of his presence & company. dost thou
not believe that he now enjoys the Incomp-
rehensable Joys of the Great God of
Heaven. doest thou not think that
all his Tears is wiped from his eyes
142
1668.
all sorrows is departed from him & he
is delivered from this body of sin & death.
oh my soul canst thou not consider
for some comfort that what he now
enjoys he would not exchange for
10000 worlds, thy loss for the present
is his gain, & God will assuredly
bring thee at the Resurrection to enjoy in, when
we shall appear together being
clothed with Immortality to enjoy these
inconceivable Joys he now does possess.
All though worms consume this body
that with my Eyes shall I see God &
behold him face to face. which this clay
this body of dust. cannot. till my
vile body be changed & this mortal
shall put on Immortality. Oh that the
Lord would now show him self to his
weak servant. & give me faith to
believe what good things is laid up
for them that love & fear him, & that
though great are the troubles
143
1668
of the Righteous yet he will deliver
them out of all. doe not there oh my
soul Repine against this great, wise. holy
& good God: for if thou belongest to
him he will give thee to know his mind
& that it is the Lord he must doe as
he will. and although this dispensa
=tion is most bitter as the cutting of
thy life be sure thou doest not sin
against him by impatience. or resist
=ing his pleasure. and although
flesh & blood cannot part willingly
Remember thou must live by faith
if ever thou expect salvation. he
was prepared for death. thou are not.
oh pray that the remainder of thy life
may be a continual preparedness &
know that this affliction is to this very end
& that as we did in this life suffer so may
we Reign together with him who is the
Author & finisher of our faith.

And daily pant & long to be
Clothed upon that death might
putt on Immortality. spending a
few days here amongst thy children
in Piety & holiness. to bring them
up in the fear & nurture of the Lord
that I may deliver up my Charge to
the Great God of Heaven with Joy
& not with grief. & in the end of my
days receive the end of my hope even
the Salvation of my Soul. where there is
no sighing. no weeping. for all tears
shall be wiped from our Eyes. then sh
shall be love with out hatred. Joy without
sorrow. delight. without anger. hopes that
is turned to enjoyment with out fears.
to loss, or to to be lost. no cares. nor Troubble
no hatred. nor envy shall enter there
for in Heaven they are as the Angels
nay higher. & drawn nearer in being
drawn & united to the nature of God
in the second person of the Trinity. the Eternall
145
1668
Son of God Blessed for ever who would
not arm themselves with those weapons that shall
enable them to fight the fight against sin
the devil & the worldly mind. shall we Love
dross above Gold. for if our Earthly Tab
ernacle were don away. we have a building
not made with hands whose maker &
builder is God. how should I groan after
& long to be clothed upon & enjoy that
happiness. those Joys. which I doe hope
my dear husband now inherits. And
now O Lord I thine poor, weak hand
-maide & servant doth from my very
soul & ♥ beg of thy Glorious Majesty
That as thou hast given me a being on
this thy Earth continued me thus long
in a multitude of innumerable dangers
Spiritual & temporal. from my Infancy
youth. Middle Ale. & towards old Age
make me to understand thy word & know
thy majesty. thy Essence. thy Attributes
To Glorify thy name. & adore thee in my
Soul & spirit: let me not serve thee with
a slavish service but with a true filial obe-
-dience thou that hast kept me from great
& presumptuous sins deliver me from every
sin be it never so small
146 1668.
That may endanger a separation bet
-twixt me & my God. O Lord take me
to thy own keeping & tuition. bless
thou thy handiwork who thou hast
bestowed so much pains about & on
whom so many mercies hast bin bestowd.
here I am speak Lord thy servant
heareth. Lord what wilt thou have me
to doe I resign my will to thy Glorious
pleasure either in life or death make
me be freed from this body of death that
I may serve thee with perfect freedom of
mind will & affections & may be holy
in spirit. Soul. & body. I have in-
devred to beat down this body of death
oh give me thy continual help &
strength to over come the remains of old
Adam. let me be sick but sound in
thee. O let my widowed Condition
be a Sanctified Estate. yea even
written upon my ♥ Holiness to the Lord
that I may be an Example of thy transend-
-ant mercies to all Posterity. that my Childr-
en may be great instruments of thy praise
& my self a Chosen vessel to set forth
thy Glory to this Generation.

Although my Afflictions be great &
heavy. sad & burdensome to this weak
body yet in thee is my strength. & my hope
my Joy & my fortress. Lord be to they servant
as thou wast unto David. who served thee with
a perfect ♥ & ready mind. Thou art the
giver thy gift is thy self. o let thy
spirit dwell in me & mine richly. & let
my later part of my days be a more
separate condition from all manner of
Evil. the Evil of sine & if it be thy will
of Punishment. but however preserve me
& my family from a dishonourable walking.
lead us in thy ways & guide me in my
steps. let me be an example of grace
Piety. holiness. humility. Chastity
& Patience. with all other most Christian
virtues necessary to lead & conduct my
life. to thy own Glory. & for thy name
Sake to give thee the honour of my Creation
that I may doe Thy will on earth as tis don
in Heaven. And I humbly beg o Lord
that the mouths of all my unjust adversaries
may be stopped. make them ashamed of
there sins. & give them true repentance
& pardon if it be thy will for them that
they may be cleansed by the
148
1668
Blood of Christ. And all these humble
petitions I crave for the only merits
& blood shedding of my dearest Savior
Jesus the Righteous who intercedeth
for us at the Throne of thy Grace even
for me & all those that love his appearing
To whom with the Glorious Father & holy
spirit. Ever blessed & Infinite blessed
Trinity. be All Possible Praise.
Adoration & thanksgiving of men &
Angels. henceforth & for Ever more.
Amen & Amen.

My dear Husband Will.m Thornton
Esquire went to Malton to sister Portington
on friday the 11th of September 1668. &
was much as he used to be of late pretty
well of his infirmity. went to malton Hill
on the next day. & to church on Sunday.
upon monday he was not well & had Pills
given him by bro.r Portington. sent for Mr
Sinkler. & told him that he knew that formerly
he had bin in much trouble of mind &
sadness for his sins & had walked uncom
-fortably for the want of the sense of
Gods favour. & in great fears & horrors
but now the Lord was pleased to make him
-selfe known to him to be a reconciled
father in Christ. & that he was at Peace
with him & did feel a great deal of
Joy & comfort inwardly in his soul
& mind. Blessing the Lord for these
his infinite mercies & hoped that he should
bless his name for ever more that he was
troubled. for now he was reconciled to
him again. & a great many of such li
like expressions as these was to the great
satisfaction of Mr
Sinkler
150
1668
who stayed with him a good while.
Then towards night my dearest fell
to be worse & more heavy & drowsy
according to the distemper & they sent
by my servant to me for the Dr which
was dispatch for immediately. & came
to him on wednesday after dinner from
Yorke Dr wittie [?] he was at that time
very weak in body but I bless God
perfect in his understanding. & having
sent Mr Comber to see him. he took
his leave of him & bid him to remember
him to his dear wife. bid me be patient
& contented with Gods hand & to submit
to his will. & to this purpose he menti
-oned to him: After which he had his
Hair cut off by the Dr order being the
latest remedy. with his own free Consent
but no remedies. or medicine. nor Art
could prevail: it being the determination
of our God to take him to him self. but
yet to mix this bitter Cup Death
with the allay of such a quiet frame
& temper free from torment or signs
151
1668.
of much pains. lying as if he
were in a sweet sleep which by degrees
growing colder at his feet & so dying
upwards drawing his breath shorter
all the Thursday morning & towards
11 a clock in the forenoon he fetched
one little sigh & sweetly resigned up
his Spirit in to the hand of his dear
Redeemer Jesus Christ.

He departed this life on Thursday the
17th of September 1668 betwixt the hours
of 11, 12 at noon. being on the June
the 2d 1668 Forty four years of
Age. we having lived a dear &
loving couple in holy marriage together
almost 17 years.

He was brought home to Newton on
friday the 18th of September &. had the company
of all his neighbours. of Gentry & friends
that could be obtained considering the time of
his interment not being to be kept
by reason of his much Physic till those
of a further distance could be had.
Those that helped to carry were of his
152
1668
Nearest Relations vidz

There was a very great congregation
as could be at that time he being most
generally beloved of his whole County
& man of Great Piety. Peace &
Honesty. & great was the Lamentati
on for such an one in general but
mine cannot be rightly weighed for
any thing in this life. yet must I
submit for the Lords sake with patience &
submission & resignation. in hopes of a
Joyful resurrection at the last day then
to be united in praising God for ever.

My dearest heart was Interred
in the Alley of his own at his own
Parish Church in Stongrave near
his own Mother & two sweet
children Joyce & Christopher.
he was Buried on Friday the 18th of
September. 1668 between the hours
of 4 & 5 by Mr Thomas Comber
who Preached his Funeral sermon.
Whose Text was in Ecclesiastes: 12th
the 1st verse. Remember now thy
Creator in the days of thy youth, while
the Evil days come not, nor the years
draw nigh; when thou shalt say,
I have no pleasure in them.

epigraph.p:
Lord he loves thee the less, that
loves any thing with thee, which he
loves not for thee.

div.l:
Since nature's works be good, and, Death
doth serve.

As natures work, why should we fear
to die.

Since fear is vain, but when it
may preserve,

Why should we fear that which we
cannot fly.

Fear is more pain than is the pain
it fears.

Disarming humane minds of
native might.

While each conceit an ugly figure
bears.

Which were not evil, well viewed
in reasons light .

Our only eyes, which dimmed with passions
be.

And scarce discern the dawn of
coming day.

Let them be cleared, and now begin
to see.
Our life is but a step. in dusty way.

Then let us hold, the bliss of peaceful
minds.

Since this we feel. great loss we
cannot find.
Leave me O Love, which reachest but to dust
And thou my mind aspire to higher things
Grow rich in that which never taketh Rust
What ever fades, but fading plea.sure brings
Draw in thy beams, & humble all. thy might
To that sweet yoke where lasting freedoms be
Which breaks the clouds, & opens forth the light
That doth both shine, & gives us sight to see
O take fast hold, let that light be thy guide

In this small course, which birth draws out to
death.
And think how evil becometh him to slide

Who seeketh Hea.ven, & comes of Heavenly
breath.
Then farewell world thy uttermost I see
Eternal love maintain thy life in me:
div.p: Amen.

div.l: Farewell the gilded follies, pleasing troubles
Farewell, the hon.red rags. the Crystal bubbles
Fame's but a hollow Echo, Gold poor clay,
Hon.or the darling, but of one short day.
Beauty's chief Idol, but a damask skin
State but a Golden Prison to live in.
To vex free minds, embroidered trains
And goodly Pageants, proudly Swelling veins
And blood allied to greatness, is but lone
Inherited, not purchased, not our own.
Fame, Riches, Hon.or Beauty, State, Birth
Are but the fading blessings of the Earth.
I would be Rich, but see man too unkind.
Digs in the bowels of the Richest mine.
I would be great, but yet the Sun doth still
Level his beams against the rising hill.
I would be fair, but see the champion proud
The worlds fair Eye oft setting in a cloud.
I would be wise, but that the fox I see.
Suspected guilty, when the fox is free.
I would be poor, but see the humble grass
Trampled upon, by each unworthy Ass.
Rich hated; wise suspected; scorned. if poor
Great feared; fair tempted; high still envied more
would the world then adopt me for her heir.
Would beauties queen entitle me the fair.
Fame speak me ho.nrs minion & could I
With Indian Angels, & a speaking Eye.
Command bare heads; bow'd knees strike Justice dumb
As well as blind & lame, & give a Tongue
To stones by Epitaphs; be called great master
In the last lines of every Poetaster:
Could I be more then any man that lives
Great, wise, rich fair. all in Superlatives
Yet I these favours would more free resign
Then ever Fortune would have had them mine.
I count one minute of my holy leisure
Beyond the mirth of all this Earthy pleasure
welcome pure thoughts. come the Sober groves
These are my guests: this is the court I loves.
The winged people of the skies, shall sing.
me Anthems by my Sellers gentle spring.
A prayer book shall be my looking glass
Wherein I will adorn sweet virtues face

Hear dwells no heartless loves no pale fact
fears
No short Joys purchased with Eternal tears.

Here will I sit & sigh my weak youth
folly.

And learn to affect an holy
melancholy.
And if contentment be a stranger, then
He ne'er look for it but in Heaven again.

div.p: The Just shall live by faith.
div.l: Christ and the Church, in love so well agreed
That he for her, & she for him has Bleed.
Thus imitate thy Saviour, in his fervent love
And then my Soul her Joys will lasting prove
Oh groundless deeps, o love without degree
The offended dies, to Set the offender free.

div.head: My Souls Wish.
div.l: Oh: Had I of his love but Part,
That chosen was by Gods own heart,
That Princely Prophet David he,
Whom in the word of truth I see.
The King of Heaven so dearly loved.
As mercy beyond measure proved;
Then should I neither Giant fear,
Nor Lyon that my Soul would tear;
Nor as the Philistines, nor such friends:
As never, were true Christians friends:
No passions should my Spirit vex.
Nor sorrow so my mind perplex.
But I should still all glory give.
Unto my God by whom I live.
And to the Glory of his Name,
Throughout the world divulge the Same:
My walk should be but in his ways,
My talk but only in his Praise.;
My Life a death, but in his Love;
My Death a life for him to Prove;
My care to keep a Conscience clean;
My Will from wicked thoughts to wean;
My Pain, and pleasure, travail, ease,
My God thus in all things to please;
Nor Earth, nor Heaven should me move,
But Still my Lord should be my love.
If I am sick, he were my health,
If I am poor, he were my wealth.
If I am weak, he is my strength,
If dead, he is my life at length;
If scorned, he only is my grace;
If banished, he my Resting-Place.
If wronged, he only is my Right.
If Sad, he were my Souls delight;
In sum, and all, All-onely he,
Should be all, above All to me.
His hand should wipe away my Tears
His favour free me from all fears
His Mercy pardon all my sin,
His Grace my life anew begin.
His love my Light to Heaven should be
His Glory this to comfort me:
And as ti's writ Such honour shall.
Even unto all his Saints befall.
Judge not that field, because it's stubble
Nor her that's poor & full of trouble.
Though t'one look bare, t'other thin,
Judge not their treasure lies within.

div.head: A Prayer.
div.p:
O Lord God of our Salvation, who for
our Sakes were wounded & didest
die to redeem our Souls from hell.
& wast pleased to lie in the Grave, that
our sins might be buried by thee, by
& act of oblivion. but thou alone of all
that ever died were free amongst the dead
to show thy Sovereignty over all, & of
thine own Power didst arise again
with victory & triumph; O Powerful
omnipotent Lord God, regard I humbly
beseech thee, the pourings out of a weak
frail despised handmaid of thine, have
mercy upon thy poor Servant, whom thou
hast made, & preserved by thy power
& might hitherto, lo thine indignation
Lieth hard upon me, & thou hast vexed
me with all thy storms ; thy hand presseth
me sore ; My soul is full of trouble by
reason of my Sins, & my life draweth
nigh
164
unto the Grave ; my body in distress
my soul under sadder calamities
by the with drawing of thy Presence, hide
not thou thy Heavenly face from me
o Lord, unless to make me seek thee with
more ardour & Zeal, O restore me to thy
favour again, & now I am brought
into a forlorn & Widowed condition
give me o Lord a double proportion of
thy Spirit to be my Illumination, & a
guide in this my Saddest Pilgrimage. thy
word a lantern to my paths & a
light unto my ways that I tread not
the steps of death, let me not go down
into the dark, nor my life into the place
where all things are forgotten, though
thou hast pleased to afflict me
sore in being deprived of the dear comf-ort
of my dear husband, make me return
thanks for so long enjoyment of him
165
& for those eminent gifts & graces
which thou in a plentiful measure had
endowed him with all. to thee be the Hon.or
given, due unto thy. name And o Lord give
me power & strength to imitate his
virtues being called to thy Service in
our youths, give me grace to take up thy
Cross daily & follow thee, being meek
& lowly in Spirit; submissive with a true
& catholic resignation to All thy wise
dispensations seem they to cross my
perverse will never so much, give me
patience throughout, in all the course of
my Life, true wisdom, faith, hope. &
Charity. Let me not lack o Lord any
thing which may adorn my Soul in thy
sight & making it lovely in sight of my
Redeemer, who Purchased it with his blood
write upon the Tables of my heart Holiness
unto the Lord, give me grace to continue a
pure mind in a pure body cleansed by
166
thy precious blood, And if it be thy
good pleasure to continue me yet a while
longer to doe thee service here, give me
my life for a prey who had deserved
to have had suffered death long ere
this but by thy goodness & bounty I am
yet remaining. O Let me beg it without
offence to thy Majesty that I might be in
a more prepared condition for the sweet
Bridegroom of my Soul. And in the interim
let me show forth the loving kindness of
the Lord amongst the Redeemed ones in the
land of the living: for the living, the living
he shall praise thee & confess thy
Holiness, & the mercies of thy holy Name
O hide not thy face from me any more.
but give me sufficient Sustentation
& Support to enable me with fortitude
& patience to endure thy fatherly
chastisements. that thou maist have the
167
Glory of all, & I to reap benifitt of
thy Rod; to be amended there by & to
walk in better obedience. give me also
I pray thee,o my God a healthy temper
of body to be the better enabled to do my
duty thou hast called me unto As a careful
& faithful mother of this Family & serve
thee with Zeal & a constant Regular devotion.
Restore, & preserve me in the life of
Righteousness, sobriety & chastity. in
my words & Actions. blessing me & mine
with happy opportunities of doing thee
that service that we are capable of in this Life.
That I may redeem the time past. & by
thy Grace may grow Rich in good works,
always abounding in the work of the
Lord, that when thou shalt demand my
Soul to be rendered up into thy hands
My soul may not be abhorred of thee.
Nor suffer thy terrors, but may feel an
Eternity of blessings in the Resurrection of
the Just; and this I most humbly beg
with the Sanctification of thy most holy Spirit
&
168
And heartily crave. at thy most
gracious hand, with all things in order
to Eternity. both for our souls & bodies
even for the Lord, Christ Jesus his
sake, the righteous. to whom with the
holy Spirit. the Eternal & Glorious
Father, Incomprehensible & ever
Blessed Trinity. Be ascribed all Hon.or
Glory. Power, might; majesty thank
-sgive, Praise, adoration & dominion
by all things in Heaven, & Earth.
of men & Angels, both now & to
all eternity for evermore.
Amen.

div.head:
Remember to insert some Remarks
for gotten in this first Book.

div.p:
vidz The great fall I had at Kirklington
when I was 3 years old in following Sara my
maid when she had my brother Christophr
in her Arms. I fell upon the corner of the
hearth stone in the Passage chamber going into
my d. mother's Chamber. The wound so Deep
that my mother saw the skin of the brain when
the scull was broken & had gone nigh
to have
killed me. But ever blessed be the name of my
gracious & Powerful God who did not cut
my life short in this moment being but a little
betwixt me & Death. Oh that I night
live to
praise the Lord most high & profitable to my
own soul Amen.

The Lord gave me a dream before the dea
th of my dear & honoured father to warn me
of his loss: & he did foretell the sorrows
& sad times coming on these Kingdoms to my
Dear mother & my self:

My Dear mother had a Terrible dream
of the day of Judgement in 39
she had one Also not Long before my Lord
of Straford & the holy King suffered which she
told me often of. & before the Scotch Rebellion
& that of Ireland. most dreadful to her.

She did see in the north window in her
Chamber the sky broke out & opened with a
dreadful noise. & like guns & swords to
war. when followed An infinite number
of People like common People & meaner sort
with Raw bond faces like Scots. & Irish, &
English all in a great confusion & hurry
as if running with Arms & a posture of
fighting & other instruments of war. These
came before with loud clamours & shouts. &
noise. Then a little distance after came
my Lord of Strafford the Lord Lieutenant
of Ireland. in mourning habit. & most
sad & Pensive walked at a space by him
self: first. & then appeared as with out a
head: After him the Bishop of Canterbury so also.
After my Lord at a good pretty distance
Appeared the perfect Person of the good
King Charles the first with the Crown on his
head, but being Pursued he looked back
in a dread fright going fast on before. And
having his sword Drawn in one hand. &
The other Arm he held over the young
Prince Charles in defending & preserving
him him from the multitude and this in a
great Concern. & seemed to fly. & having
his Robes & Crown on his head.

Then Pursued an infinite innumerable
company & Multitude of all sorts of men
& in so Terrible & dreadful a manner. that
it affrighted my D. mother very much & in
Pursuance of the King to take him. All
the while of this appearance. Loud noise
& shouts & Rude Tumults in great
horror with Arms &, guns. And all the
while this appeared which was so distinct
& perfect that she did believe she really saw
the Real sight the sky was so clear and
at noon time a day: which lasted about
an hour or more. to her very great
fear & affrightment..

within a little while, my father came
up into the Chamber to see her. when she
being extremely troubled told him this thing
he heard her with Patience & when she
asked him what he thought of this great
sight. he would not show to her his trouble
but said dreams was not to be believed
but bid her w refer all to the divine
Providence. yet he was observed to be
very sad. And after & before this said
That there was a dreadful cloud hang
over these Churches & Nations. which she
would live to see. but as for his part. he
did believe his Eyes should not live to see them
but most Christian like begged of God to
prevent and hinder those calamities to
fall on the Church & Kingdoms & prayed
heartily for our good King; said that Pride &
fullness of Bread would be the fall of the
Church & state if God prevented not.
with many other like Prophetical sayings
several times with much trouble & some
still begging to God to Divert his Judgment
And on his death bed did sadly bemoan &
pity me in particular. saying with a sigh.
A poor child with miseries must thou live
to see. & with a groan Tuned him a bout.
which Pity of my d. father & his earnest look,
did never go out of my ♥. But the effects I
have found of his foreseeing Predictions on
both Church. State. families & Persons most
dear to this holy: wise. & good Christian.

I had a very significant dream in 45
immediately before my d. sister Danby died
I did see her laid on the child bed all in white
& as if she were asleep. coming to her
looked with in the curtains but she appeared to me
to be dead at which I cried out
being much affrighted & said she was
Really dead. & there I a waked in grief
with in a little space. she fell into Labour
of Franke her 19th Child. and sent for my
mother & my self to Hipswell. I going to
her. did find her laid in a Cough like to
my dream which did amaze me. yet she
lived to bring forth that son in infinite ex-
treamty & quite different from all the other
The child coming double with his buttocks
all the way. & so exquisite torments to
that poor soul. which was not at all like as
in her other Child. bed. getting no sleep at
all for 12 nights. but one day when
Ant Norton was there she fell into a slumber
a little while then started out of it And
told my Aunt I have had the strangest dream
that ever I had. I dreamt that A man came in
to the Room. with all Things for mournings
& laid them on the ground. [Sir?] B [M/W?] habits
as sleeves &. I said she asked what that meant
The man that brought the mournings. said That
when such things appeared in a Child wife's
Chamber. It was a sign that that woman that
laid since should dye. Then my sister said
Is not this an odd Dream. My A. N. said
to her that dreams was but fables not to believed
then my sister replied Gods will be don she desired
to die & be with Christ. which was best of All: which
with in a months space she did. having suffered many
sorrows & troubles through which I hope she entered into
the Kingdom of God: Amen:

I had a sad dream half a year before my
Brother George Wandesford was lost. That he was
going over this River and that it did Rise then
when he was in it. which so over came him. That he
could make no help for him self. And so was
drowned in it. This Dream did trouble me much
& I waked in grief. but. seeing it but a dream
I prayed it might never come to Pass. and fell a
sleep again And dreamt the second time the same
which wakened me in much grief & fear. falling into
a great sorrow & Trembling. till the morning.
And then I was in trouble when my dear Brother
George came into the Chamber & asked me what made
me weep so sore. I answered it was for him. why sad
he sister doest thou weep for me. I said because he
was so venturous to go over that dangerous River
Swale & that I feared he might be lost in it. And
begged of him for Gods sake that he would not presume to
go so when it was high for I feared him much that
a flood should destroy him. for I had had a dreadful
Dream that night concerning it And told him all the
circumstances of it

At which he gave a sight , and said for my sake
he would not venture again. but have a care
of him self & gave me his hand he would not go
over it again when it was high. which pleased me
to hear this Resolution: nor did he ever till that
day of his death gon that way after: And then
was compelled to it by Reason of shortness of time.
It was on Easter Monday. when he came from Mr
Darcys (Henry): he having the Easter day by Gods
mercy bin prepared to Receive the Holy Sacrament
& to my great Joy did take it with my dear mother
& my self & my brother Christophr, one thing
must not be forgotten. That there had bin a great
falling out betwixt G. W: & C: W my brothers about
the menservants that made debate amongst them
so that they would not have received that holy feast.
But it pleased God to give me that blessing. That I did
use all my utmost endeavours to Reconcile them
by all Christian Persuasion. which I humbly Praise God
for I did at that time And they were in perfect Charity
each to others & did both receive very Reverently
on Easter day in Hipswell Chapell with my D. mother
& my self. But in the Affter noone my brother
G: W: did go to see Mr Henry Darcy. and finding
him not at home, entertained him self with old motther>
Darcy. & he took a Bible and read a chapter to he[r]
& did make such an admirable exposition on it
That she protested she did never hear the like
at which she admired & said. Sir I ever took you
to be a fine gentleman. & well bred. but I did
not think you had bin so good a scholar & a divine
At which my D: brother answered with a deep sigh &
said Ah Mrs Darcy I have had the best advantagee
of a Religious education & Piety by my dear
Parents as any man Living. & has understood
my duty to God &. but God knows such has bin
my troubles & vexations of the world & the
madness of my enemies Against me that I have
not followed what I should but bin extravagant
more then I would. But if it please God to bless
me with life. you shall see me become a new
man by his grace. & I will set my self to doe
glory to God & good in my Country. The Lord forgive
me what is Past and I will for sake what is amiss
which words she said proceeded with great earnestness
& was a great Joy to her to hear them but the Lord
was not pleased to grant him a long life but to take
him away in these good designs. & what he wanted
in Power God accepted in the will in him.
He Laid that night there. And the next mor=ning
came to Hipswell about 9 a clock. And at that time
found me in a most sad circumstance. I had bin
coming my head & on a sudden there was a
most grievous Pain struck in to my Sinews of
my neck which was so intolerable. That,
I could not hold my Tongue from Crying out
nor to hold my neck straight it being so
much contracted in the maine sinews. but
was tormented for an hour together. At
which time my brother came in to the Chamber &
kneeling down very Reverently asked
blessing. Then came to me in a fright asked me what
ailed me to cry so grievously out. Oh said I
dear brother I am in greater torment then I
could express. all did amaze at this, but
thought it to be cold. & he had pity on me Lord
god help me dear heart. And said he was
in great hast to write to London to Mr R. Darly
to thank him for clearing his sequestration
& the Post would be gon. asked If my mother would
write. she said that I was so gravely ill she could
not leave me but doe it afterwards. So he did
Again kneel down and ask blessing. she said
son you asked blessing but a Nothre you came in
he said that he could not have to much of her prayers
for him & so Reverently bid her good morrow
& me farewell. And took horse to go to Rich
mond.

A grateful Remembrance of
what God did for me in deliverance fr[om]
a miscarriage by a fright & sorrow
for Nettletons bailiffs distraining all
I had which was delivered by a deed
in June 1661.

It was my dear Husban
Husbands misfortune to enter
upon the Assignment of Mr Norton
of the Irish Estate of my d. father by
the advice of his uncle Darley as that
he might have had more power to
have all my mother's dues out of Irld
for 19 years She lived after my fathers
Death of 360 pound a year. but he
did not demand it for her. but he
did engage for for my Fathers Debts
by the mitigation of some who did it
to clear themselves. And by that means
did involve his own Estate to secure
them which did prove fatal to ours.

And tho Sr John Lowther did
offer my dear mother in my hearing to
give her for my brother Ch. 1500l
for her Interest in Ireland. Butt my
uncle Rich. Darley would not let her
Accept of this motion. But said that he
might have all her Arrears which came to
the some of 7000l But tho she did
make a Deed of Trust to Trustees to
me for my sake. and gave me all of
it. except 130l due to my Lord Danby
for a Deb of my brother G. wand. wards
ship which my uncle Osborn paid for him that
Sir Ch wand would not pay it till he was
forced by suit. for which I was called on
by my Lord Danby to give testimony.
But as to my dear husband he had
entered into A statute to Mr Nettleton
of a thousand Pound to pay a Debt
of my fathers which was but 500l a first
but being above 20 years due did
come to 1000l
which some my d husband did
pay Nettlton all but 100l- which he
was in dispute with him for he had
received it but would not give up
his bond & statute without the payment
of it. But I was so terrified at a
suit that I told my dear Husband
it was best to borrow and pay it that we
might get quit of him But my der
Husband would not but said that he
demanded it falsely & would not
pay it. I said I had a friend that would
lend him meaning that my mother had
given it me. but he would not do it
Mr Th. was to go to London about
it to quit him. And when we was
new come to our House at Newton
to live he went to London about it
and left me big with Child of my 7t
Child my son Robert Thornton. & he
went away before we were settled
Tho I had brought all my d. mothers.
goods to furnish the house. before I came
into it. nor had the neighbours come
to welcome us into our house as is the
Custom of the Country before Mr Th went
tho they did do it to me in his absence &
was very kind to me.

But when he was gon to London
one day in the morning. I fell into a dream
being alone in bed That Mr Netletons
Bailiff was come to distrain all my
goods for that Debt. & put me into a
great fright when I wakened & that
my made Jane flour came into my Chamber
& to bed side asked me if I was a wake
I asked her to tell me truly whether was
Nettletons bailiffs come. she being in a wonder
asked who had bin here. I said none
for she looked me me in.

At last she said they was there. but prayed
me not to be frighted for they was civill.
I said Sir wand should pay it. But they
would not go with out the money so it was
much grief to me tho I had bin lost if
I had not had the Dream before hand.
I bless the Lord my God for my delivery
from death & miscarriage of my dear
Child. But I by Providence. had
received 100l of my Portion that week & had
that 58l was my Dear Mothers that
I had in the house which I paid to them
& so they got 158l of me that tim
which by Gods mercy did stop there mouths
And I was delivered from Death then
tho I was brought very low.

Thus did the great & gracious father
of mercies deliver me by giving me
warning by a dream which did prevnt
my greater destruction.

There fore will I bless & Praise the
Name of God forever who watched
over me in my sleep to keep me from
that Ruin. And I will praise the Lord
for Ever more. Amen

The great Deliverance I had from
A Rape by Captaine Innis a Scott
who did swear to Ravish me from
my dear mothers ground when I had
gon to Cows with her maids But that
his own servant that I cured of a
wound did discover it to me & I was
saved. blessed be my God for ever
more Amen

my great deliverance from
being stolen away out of my
mothers Pasture which was laid
wait for me by Mr Jerimy
Smithson when I was at Hipsw
& I would not endure his suite
by his friends. He had laid
wait to have catched me from
my mother's Pasture when I went
from to Cowes. But by a poor
mans means Tho. Binks he did
pray me not to go out of the
house for that man had sworn
to lay wait to have Catchd me by
some others & to have forced me to
mary me or destroy me. but the
Lord have mercy on me & delivered
me out of the Devil's Temptation
I will glorify the name of God for
Ever more Amen:
